scene.title: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: In delivering my son from me, I bury a second husband.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: And I in going, madam, weep o'er my father's death anew: but I must attend his majesty's command, to whom I am now in ward, evermore in subjection.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: You shall find of the king a husband, madam; you, sir, a father: he that so generally is at all times good must of necessity hold his virtue to you; whose worthiness would stir it up where it wanted rather than lack it where there is such abundance.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: What hope is there of his majesty's amendment?

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: He hath abandoned his physicians, madam; under whose practises he hath persecuted time with hope, and finds no other advantage in the process but only the losing of hope by time.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: This young gentlewoman had a father,--O, that 'had'! how sad a passage 'tis!--whose skill was almost as great as his honesty; had it stretched so far, would have made nature immortal, and death should have play for lack of work. Would, for the king's sake, he were living! I think it would be the death of the king's disease.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: How called you the man you speak of, madam?

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: He was famous, sir, in his profession, and it was his great right to be so: Gerard de Narbon.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: He was excellent indeed, madam: the king very lately spoke of him admiringly and mourningly: he was skilful enough to have lived still, if knowledge could be set up against mortality.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: What is it, my good lord, the king languishes of?

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: A fistula, my lord.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I heard not of it before.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I would it were not notorious. Was this gentlewoman the daughter of Gerard de Narbon?

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: His sole child, my lord, and bequeathed to my overlooking. I have those hopes of her good that her education promises; her dispositions she inherits, which makes fair gifts fairer; for where an unclean mind carries virtuous qualities, there commendations go with pity; they are virtues and traitors too; in her they are the better for their simpleness; she derives her honesty and achieves her goodness.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Your commendations, madam, get from her tears.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: 'Tis the best brine a maiden can season her praise in. The remembrance of her father never approaches her heart but the tyranny of her sorrows takes all livelihood from her cheek. No more of this, Helena; go to, no more; lest it be rather thought you affect a sorrow than have it.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I do affect a sorrow indeed, but I have it too.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Moderate lamentation is the right of the dead, excessive grief the enemy to the living.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: If the living be enemy to the grief, the excess makes it soon mortal.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Madam, I desire your holy wishes.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: How understand we that?

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Be thou blest, Bertram, and succeed thy father In manners, as in shape! thy blood and virtue Contend for empire in thee, and thy goodness Share with thy birthright! Love all, trust a few, Do wrong to none: be able for thine enemy Rather in power than use, and keep thy friend Under thy own life's key: be cheque'd for silence, But never tax'd for speech. What heaven more will, That thee may furnish and my prayers pluck down, Fall on thy head! Farewell, my lord; 'Tis an unseason'd courtier; good my lord, Advise him.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: He cannot want the best That shall attend his love.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS of Rousillon, HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Heaven bless him! Farewell, Bertram.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: The best wishes that can be forged in your thoughts be servants to you! Be comfortable to my mother, your mistress, and make much of her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Farewell, pretty lady: you must hold the credit of your father.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: O, were that all! I think not on my father; And these great tears grace his remembrance more Than those I shed for him. What was he like? I have forgot him: my imagination Carries no favour in't but Bertram's. I am undone: there is no living, none, If Bertram be away. 'Twere all one That I should love a bright particular star And think to wed it, he is so above me: In his bright radiance and collateral light Must I be comforted, not in his sphere. The ambition in my love thus plagues itself: The hind that would be mated by the lion Must die for love. 'Twas pretty, though plague, To see him every hour; to sit and draw His arched brows, his hawking eye, his curls, In our heart's table; heart too capable Of every line and trick of his sweet favour: But now he's gone, and my idolatrous fancy Must sanctify his reliques. Who comes here? One that goes with him: I love him for his sake; And yet I know him a notorious liar, Think him a great way fool, solely a coward; Yet these fixed evils sit so fit in him, That they take place, when virtue's steely bones Look bleak i' the cold wind: withal, full oft we see Cold wisdom waiting on superfluous folly.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Save you, fair queen!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: And you, monarch!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: No.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: And no.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Are you meditating on virginity?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Ay. You have some stain of soldier in you: let me ask you a question. Man is enemy to virginity; how may we barricado it against him?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Keep him out.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: But he assails; and our virginity, though valiant, in the defence yet is weak: unfold to us some warlike resistance.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: There is none: man, sitting down before you, will undermine you and blow you up.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Bless our poor virginity from underminers and blowers up! Is there no military policy, how virgins might blow up men?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Virginity being blown down, man will quicklier be blown up: marry, in blowing him down again, with the breach yourselves made, you lose your city. It is not politic in the commonwealth of nature to preserve virginity. Loss of virginity is rational increase and there was never virgin got till virginity was first lost. That you were made of is metal to make virgins. Virginity by being once lost may be ten times found; by being ever kept, it is ever lost: 'tis too cold a companion; away with 't!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I will stand for 't a little, though therefore I die a virgin.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: There's little can be said in 't; 'tis against the rule of nature. To speak on the part of virginity, is to accuse your mothers; which is most infallible disobedience. He that hangs himself is a virgin: virginity murders itself and should be buried in highways out of all sanctified limit, as a desperate offendress against nature. Virginity breeds mites, much like a cheese; consumes itself to the very paring, and so dies with feeding his own stomach. Besides, virginity is peevish, proud, idle, made of self-love, which is the most inhibited sin in the canon. Keep it not; you cannot choose but loose by't: out with 't! within ten year it will make itself ten, which is a goodly increase; and the principal itself not much the worse: away with 't!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: How might one do, sir, to lose it to her own liking?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Let me see: marry, ill, to like him that ne'er it likes. 'Tis a commodity will lose the gloss with lying; the longer kept, the less worth: off with 't while 'tis vendible; answer the time of request. Virginity, like an old courtier, wears her cap out of fashion: richly suited, but unsuitable: just like the brooch and the tooth-pick, which wear not now. Your date is better in your pie and your porridge than in your cheek; and your virginity, your old virginity, is like one of our French withered pears, it looks ill, it eats drily; marry, 'tis a withered pear; it was formerly better; marry, yet 'tis a withered pear: will you anything with it?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Not my virginity yet There shall your master have a thousand loves, A mother and a mistress and a friend, A phoenix, captain and an enemy, A guide, a goddess, and a sovereign, A counsellor, a traitress, and a dear; His humble ambition, proud humility, His jarring concord, and his discord dulcet, His faith, his sweet disaster; with a world Of pretty, fond, adoptious christendoms, That blinking Cupid gossips. Now shall he-- I know not what he shall. God send him well! The court's a learning place, and he is one--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: What one, i' faith?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: That I wish well. 'Tis pity--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: What's pity?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: That wishing well had not a body in't, Which might be felt; that we, the poorer born, Whose baser stars do shut us up in wishes, Might with effects of them follow our friends, And show what we alone must think, which never Return us thanks.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Monsieur Parolles, my lord calls for you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Little Helen, farewell; if I can remember thee, I will think of thee at court.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Monsieur Parolles, you were born under a charitable star.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Under Mars, I.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I especially think, under Mars.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Why under Mars?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: The wars have so kept you under that you must needs be born under Mars.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: When he was predominant.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: When he was retrograde, I think, rather.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Why think you so?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: You go so much backward when you fight.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: That's for advantage.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I am so full of businesses, I cannot answer thee acutely. I will return perfect courtier; in the which, my instruction shall serve to naturalize thee, so thou wilt be capable of a courtier's counsel and understand what advice shall thrust upon thee; else thou diest in thine unthankfulness, and thine ignorance makes thee away: farewell. When thou hast leisure, say thy prayers; when thou hast none, remember thy friends; get thee a good husband, and use him as he uses thee; so, farewell.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Our remedies oft in ourselves do lie, Which we ascribe to heaven: the fated sky Gives us free scope, only doth backward pull Our slow designs when we ourselves are dull. What power is it which mounts my love so high, That makes me see, and cannot feed mine eye? The mightiest space in fortune nature brings To join like likes and kiss like native things. Impossible be strange attempts to those That weigh their pains in sense and do suppose What hath been cannot be: who ever strove So show her merit, that did miss her love? The king's disease--my project may deceive me, But my intents are fix'd and will not leave me.

scene.title: SCENE II. Paris. The KING's palace.

speech.stagedir: Flourish of cornets. Enter the KING of France, with letters, and divers Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Paris. The KING's palace.

speech.stagedir: Flourish of cornets. Enter the KING of France, with letters, and divers Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: So 'tis reported, sir.

speech.stagedir: Flourish of cornets. Enter the KING of France, with letters, and divers Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Nay, 'tis most credible; we here received it A certainty, vouch'd from our cousin Austria, With caution that the Florentine will move us For speedy aid; wherein our dearest friend Prejudicates the business and would seem To have us make denial.

speech.stagedir: Flourish of cornets. Enter the KING of France, with letters, and divers Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: His love and wisdom, Approved so to your majesty, may plead For amplest credence.

speech.stagedir: Flourish of cornets. Enter the KING of France, with letters, and divers Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: He hath arm'd our answer, And Florence is denied before he comes: Yet, for our gentlemen that mean to see The Tuscan service, freely have they leave To stand on either part.

speech.stagedir: Flourish of cornets. Enter the KING of France, with letters, and divers Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: It well may serve A nursery to our gentry, who are sick For breathing and exploit.

speech.stagedir: Flourish of cornets. Enter the KING of France, with letters, and divers Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: What's he comes here?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: It is the Count Rousillon, my good lord, Young Bertram.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Youth, thou bear'st thy father's face; Frank nature, rather curious than in haste, Hath well composed thee. Thy father's moral parts Mayst thou inherit too! Welcome to Paris.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: My thanks and duty are your majesty's.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I would I had that corporal soundness now, As when thy father and myself in friendship First tried our soldiership! He did look far Into the service of the time and was Discipled of the bravest: he lasted long; But on us both did haggish age steal on And wore us out of act. It much repairs me To talk of your good father. In his youth He had the wit which I can well observe To-day in our young lords; but they may jest Till their own scorn return to them unnoted Ere they can hide their levity in honour; So like a courtier, contempt nor bitterness Were in his pride or sharpness; if they were, His equal had awaked them, and his honour, Clock to itself, knew the true minute when Exception bid him speak, and at this time His tongue obey'd his hand: who were below him He used as creatures of another place And bow'd his eminent top to their low ranks, Making them proud of his humility, In their poor praise he humbled. Such a man Might be a copy to these younger times; Which, follow'd well, would demonstrate them now But goers backward.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: His good remembrance, sir, Lies richer in your thoughts than on his tomb; So in approof lives not his epitaph As in your royal speech.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Would I were with him! He would always say-- Methinks I hear him now; his plausive words He scatter'd not in ears, but grafted them, To grow there and to bear,--'Let me not live,'-- This his good melancholy oft began, On the catastrophe and heel of pastime, When it was out,--'Let me not live,' quoth he, 'After my flame lacks oil, to be the snuff Of younger spirits, whose apprehensive senses All but new things disdain; whose judgments are Mere fathers of their garments; whose constancies Expire before their fashions.' This he wish'd; I after him do after him wish too, Since I nor wax nor honey can bring home, I quickly were dissolved from my hive, To give some labourers room.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: You are loved, sir: They that least lend it you shall lack you first.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I fill a place, I know't. How long is't, count, Since the physician at your father's died? He was much famed.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Some six months since, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: If he were living, I would try him yet. Lend me an arm; the rest have worn me out With several applications; nature and sickness Debate it at their leisure. Welcome, count; My son's no dearer.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Thank your majesty.

scene.title: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I will now hear; what say you of this gentlewoman?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Madam, the care I have had to even your content, I wish might be found in the calendar of my past endeavours; for then we wound our modesty and make foul the clearness of our deservings, when of ourselves we publish them.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: What does this knave here? Get you gone, sirrah: the complaints I have heard of you I do not all believe: 'tis my slowness that I do not; for I know you lack not folly to commit them, and have ability enough to make such knaveries yours.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: 'Tis not unknown to you, madam, I am a poor fellow.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Well, sir.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: No, madam, 'tis not so well that I am poor, though many of the rich are damned: but, if I may have your ladyship's good will to go to the world, Isbel the woman and I will do as we may.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Wilt thou needs be a beggar?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I do beg your good will in this case.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: In what case?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: In Isbel's case and mine own. Service is no heritage: and I think I shall never have the blessing of God till I have issue o' my body; for they say barnes are blessings.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Tell me thy reason why thou wilt marry.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: My poor body, madam, requires it: I am driven on by the flesh; and he must needs go that the devil drives.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Is this all your worship's reason?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Faith, madam, I have other holy reasons such as they are.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: May the world know them?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I have been, madam, a wicked creature, as you and all flesh and blood are; and, indeed, I do marry that I may repent.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Thy marriage, sooner than thy wickedness.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I am out o' friends, madam; and I hope to have friends for my wife's sake.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Such friends are thine enemies, knave.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: You're shallow, madam, in great friends; for the knaves come to do that for me which I am aweary of. He that ears my land spares my team and gives me leave to in the crop; if I be his cuckold, he's my drudge: he that comforts my wife is the cherisher of my flesh and blood; he that cherishes my flesh and blood loves my flesh and blood; he that loves my flesh and blood is my friend: ergo, he that kisses my wife is my friend. If men could be contented to be what they are, there were no fear in marriage; for young Charbon the Puritan and old Poysam the Papist, howsome'er their hearts are severed in religion, their heads are both one; they may jowl horns together, like any deer i' the herd.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Wilt thou ever be a foul-mouthed and calumnious knave?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: A prophet I, madam; and I speak the truth the next way: For I the ballad will repeat, Which men full true shall find; Your marriage comes by destiny, Your cuckoo sings by kind.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Get you gone, sir; I'll talk with you more anon.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: May it please you, madam, that he bid Helen come to you: of her I am to speak.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Sirrah, tell my gentlewoman I would speak with her; Helen, I mean.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Was this fair face the cause, quoth she, Why the Grecians sacked Troy? Fond done, done fond, Was this King Priam's joy? With that she sighed as she stood, With that she sighed as she stood, And gave this sentence then; Among nine bad if one be good, Among nine bad if one be good, There's yet one good in ten.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: What, one good in ten? you corrupt the song, sirrah.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: One good woman in ten, madam; which is a purifying o' the song: would God would serve the world so all the year! we'ld find no fault with the tithe-woman, if I were the parson. One in ten, quoth a'! An we might have a good woman born but one every blazing star, or at an earthquake, 'twould mend the lottery well: a man may draw his heart out, ere a' pluck one.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: You'll be gone, sir knave, and do as I command you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: That man should be at woman's command, and yet no hurt done! Though honesty be no puritan, yet it will do no hurt; it will wear the surplice of humility over the black gown of a big heart. I am going, forsooth: the business is for Helen to come hither.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Well, now.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I know, madam, you love your gentlewoman entirely.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Faith, I do: her father bequeathed her to me; and she herself, without other advantage, may lawfully make title to as much love as she finds: there is more owing her than is paid; and more shall be paid her than she'll demand.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Madam, I was very late more near her than I think she wished me: alone she was, and did communicate to herself her own words to her own ears; she thought, I dare vow for her, they touched not any stranger sense. Her matter was, she loved your son: Fortune, she said, was no goddess, that had put such difference betwixt their two estates; Love no god, that would not extend his might, only where qualities were level; Dian no queen of virgins, that would suffer her poor knight surprised, without rescue in the first assault or ransom afterward. This she delivered in the most bitter touch of sorrow that e'er I heard virgin exclaim in: which I held my duty speedily to acquaint you withal; sithence, in the loss that may happen, it concerns you something to know it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: You have discharged this honestly; keep it to yourself: many likelihoods informed me of this before, which hung so tottering in the balance that I could neither believe nor misdoubt. Pray you, leave me: stall this in your bosom; and I thank you for your honest care: I will speak with you further anon. Even so it was with me when I was young: If ever we are nature's, these are ours; this thorn Doth to our rose of youth rightly belong; Our blood to us, this to our blood is born; It is the show and seal of nature's truth, Where love's strong passion is impress'd in youth: By our remembrances of days foregone, Such were our faults, or then we thought them none. Her eye is sick on't: I observe her now.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: What is your pleasure, madam?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: You know, Helen, I am a mother to you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Mine honourable mistress.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Nay, a mother: Why not a mother? When I said 'a mother,' Methought you saw a serpent: what's in 'mother,' That you start at it? I say, I am your mother; And put you in the catalogue of those That were enwombed mine: 'tis often seen Adoption strives with nature and choice breeds A native slip to us from foreign seeds: You ne'er oppress'd me with a mother's groan, Yet I express to you a mother's care: God's mercy, maiden! does it curd thy blood To say I am thy mother? What's the matter, That this distemper'd messenger of wet, The many-colour'd Iris, rounds thine eye? Why? that you are my daughter?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: That I am not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I say, I am your mother.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Pardon, madam; The Count Rousillon cannot be my brother: I am from humble, he from honour'd name; No note upon my parents, his all noble: My master, my dear lord he is; and I His servant live, and will his vassal die: He must not be my brother.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Nor I your mother?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: You are my mother, madam; would you were,-- So that my lord your son were not my brother,-- Indeed my mother! or were you both our mothers, I care no more for than I do for heaven, So I were not his sister. Can't no other, But, I your daughter, he must be my brother?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Yes, Helen, you might be my daughter-in-law: God shield you mean it not! daughter and mother So strive upon your pulse. What, pale again? My fear hath catch'd your fondness: now I see The mystery of your loneliness, and find Your salt tears' head: now to all sense 'tis gross You love my son; invention is ashamed, Against the proclamation of thy passion, To say thou dost not: therefore tell me true; But tell me then, 'tis so; for, look thy cheeks Confess it, th' one to th' other; and thine eyes See it so grossly shown in thy behaviors That in their kind they speak it: only sin And hellish obstinacy tie thy tongue, That truth should be suspected. Speak, is't so? If it be so, you have wound a goodly clew; If it be not, forswear't: howe'er, I charge thee, As heaven shall work in me for thine avail, Tell me truly.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Good madam, pardon me!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Do you love my son?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Your pardon, noble mistress!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Love you my son?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Do not you love him, madam?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Go not about; my love hath in't a bond, Whereof the world takes note: come, come, disclose The state of your affection; for your passions Have to the full appeach'd.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Then, I confess, Here on my knee, before high heaven and you, That before you, and next unto high heaven, I love your son. My friends were poor, but honest; so's my love: Be not offended; for it hurts not him That he is loved of me: I follow him not By any token of presumptuous suit; Nor would I have him till I do deserve him; Yet never know how that desert should be. I know I love in vain, strive against hope; Yet in this captious and intenible sieve I still pour in the waters of my love And lack not to lose still: thus, Indian-like, Religious in mine error, I adore The sun, that looks upon his worshipper, But knows of him no more. My dearest madam, Let not your hate encounter with my love For loving where you do: but if yourself, Whose aged honour cites a virtuous youth, Did ever in so true a flame of liking Wish chastely and love dearly, that your Dian Was both herself and love: O, then, give pity To her, whose state is such that cannot choose But lend and give where she is sure to lose; That seeks not to find that her search implies, But riddle-like lives sweetly where she dies!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Had you not lately an intent,--speak truly,-- To go to Paris?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Madam, I had.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Wherefore? tell true.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I will tell truth; by grace itself I swear. You know my father left me some prescriptions Of rare and proved effects, such as his reading And manifest experience had collected For general sovereignty; and that he will'd me In heedfull'st reservation to bestow them, As notes whose faculties inclusive were More than they were in note: amongst the rest, There is a remedy, approved, set down, To cure the desperate languishings whereof The king is render'd lost.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: This was your motive For Paris, was it? speak.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: My lord your son made me to think of this; Else Paris and the medicine and the king Had from the conversation of my thoughts Haply been absent then.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: But think you, Helen, If you should tender your supposed aid, He would receive it? he and his physicians Are of a mind; he, that they cannot help him, They, that they cannot help: how shall they credit A poor unlearned virgin, when the schools, Embowell'd of their doctrine, have left off The danger to itself?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: There's something in't, More than my father's skill, which was the greatest Of his profession, that his good receipt Shall for my legacy be sanctified By the luckiest stars in heaven: and, would your honour But give me leave to try success, I'ld venture The well-lost life of mine on his grace's cure By such a day and hour.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Dost thou believe't?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Ay, madam, knowingly.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Why, Helen, thou shalt have my leave and love, Means and attendants and my loving greetings To those of mine in court: I'll stay at home And pray God's blessing into thy attempt: Be gone to-morrow; and be sure of this, What I can help thee to thou shalt not miss.

scene.title: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.

speech.stagedir: Flourish of cornets. Enter the KING, attended with divers young Lords taking leave for the Florentine war; BERTRAM, and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Farewell, young lords; these warlike principles Do not throw from you: and you, my lords, farewell: Share the advice betwixt you; if both gain, all The gift doth stretch itself as 'tis received, And is enough for both.

speech.stagedir: Flourish of cornets. Enter the KING, attended with divers young Lords taking leave for the Florentine war; BERTRAM, and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: 'Tis our hope, sir, After well enter'd soldiers, to return And find your grace in health.

speech.stagedir: Flourish of cornets. Enter the KING, attended with divers young Lords taking leave for the Florentine war; BERTRAM, and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: No, no, it cannot be; and yet my heart Will not confess he owes the malady That doth my life besiege. Farewell, young lords; Whether I live or die, be you the sons Of worthy Frenchmen: let higher Italy,-- Those bated that inherit but the fall Of the last monarchy,--see that you come Not to woo honour, but to wed it; when The bravest questant shrinks, find what you seek, That fame may cry you loud: I say, farewell.

speech.stagedir: Flourish of cornets. Enter the KING, attended with divers young Lords taking leave for the Florentine war; BERTRAM, and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Health, at your bidding, serve your majesty!

speech.stagedir: Flourish of cornets. Enter the KING, attended with divers young Lords taking leave for the Florentine war; BERTRAM, and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Those girls of Italy, take heed of them: They say, our French lack language to deny, If they demand: beware of being captives, Before you serve.

speech.stagedir: Flourish of cornets. Enter the KING, attended with divers young Lords taking leave for the Florentine war; BERTRAM, and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Our hearts receive your warnings.

speech.stagedir: Flourish of cornets. Enter the KING, attended with divers young Lords taking leave for the Florentine war; BERTRAM, and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Farewell. Come hither to me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: O, my sweet lord, that you will stay behind us!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: 'Tis not his fault, the spark.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: O, 'tis brave wars!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Most admirable: I have seen those wars.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I am commanded here, and kept a coil with 'Too young' and 'the next year' and ''tis too early.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: An thy mind stand to't, boy, steal away bravely.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I shall stay here the forehorse to a smock, Creaking my shoes on the plain masonry, Till honour be bought up and no sword worn But one to dance with! By heaven, I'll steal away.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: There's honour in the theft.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Commit it, count.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I am your accessary; and so, farewell.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I grow to you, and our parting is a tortured body.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Farewell, captain.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Sweet Monsieur Parolles!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Noble heroes, my sword and yours are kin. Good sparks and lustrous, a word, good metals: you shall find in the regiment of the Spinii one Captain Spurio, with his cicatrice, an emblem of war, here on his sinister cheek; it was this very sword entrenched it: say to him, I live; and observe his reports for me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: We shall, noble captain.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Mars dote on you for his novices! what will ye do?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Stay: the king.

speech.stagedir: Re-enter KING. BERTRAM and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Use a more spacious ceremony to the noble lords; you have restrained yourself within the list of too cold an adieu: be more expressive to them: for they wear themselves in the cap of the time, there do muster true gait, eat, speak, and move under the influence of the most received star; and though the devil lead the measure, such are to be followed: after them, and take a more dilated farewell.

speech.stagedir: Re-enter KING. BERTRAM and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: And I will do so.

speech.stagedir: Re-enter KING. BERTRAM and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Worthy fellows; and like to prove most sinewy sword-men.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Pardon, my lord, for me and for my tidings.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I'll fee thee to stand up.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Then here's a man stands, that has brought his pardon. I would you had kneel'd, my lord, to ask me mercy, And that at my bidding you could so stand up.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I would I had; so I had broke thy pate, And ask'd thee mercy for't.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Good faith, across: but, my good lord 'tis thus; Will you be cured of your infirmity?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: No.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: O, will you eat no grapes, my royal fox? Yes, but you will my noble grapes, an if My royal fox could reach them: I have seen a medicine That's able to breathe life into a stone, Quicken a rock, and make you dance canary With spritely fire and motion; whose simple touch, Is powerful to araise King Pepin, nay, To give great Charlemain a pen in's hand, And write to her a love-line.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: What 'her' is this?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Why, Doctor She: my lord, there's one arrived, If you will see her: now, by my faith and honour, If seriously I may convey my thoughts In this my light deliverance, I have spoke With one that, in her sex, her years, profession, Wisdom and constancy, hath amazed me more Than I dare blame my weakness: will you see her For that is her demand, and know her business? That done, laugh well at me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Now, good Lafeu, Bring in the admiration; that we with thee May spend our wonder too, or take off thine By wondering how thou took'st it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Nay, I'll fit you, And not be all day neither.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Thus he his special nothing ever prologues.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Nay, come your ways.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: This haste hath wings indeed.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Nay, come your ways: This is his majesty; say your mind to him: A traitor you do look like; but such traitors His majesty seldom fears: I am Cressid's uncle, That dare leave two together; fare you well.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Now, fair one, does your business follow us?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I knew him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: The rather will I spare my praises towards him: Knowing him is enough. On's bed of death Many receipts he gave me: chiefly one. Which, as the dearest issue of his practise, And of his old experience the oily darling, He bade me store up, as a triple eye, Safer than mine own two, more dear; I have so; And hearing your high majesty is touch'd With that malignant cause wherein the honour Of my dear father's gift stands chief in power, I come to tender it and my appliance With all bound humbleness.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: We thank you, maiden; But may not be so credulous of cure, When our most learned doctors leave us and The congregated college have concluded That labouring art can never ransom nature From her inaidible estate; I say we must not So stain our judgment, or corrupt our hope, To prostitute our past-cure malady To empirics, or to dissever so Our great self and our credit, to esteem A senseless help when help past sense we deem.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: My duty then shall pay me for my pains: I will no more enforce mine office on you. Humbly entreating from your royal thoughts A modest one, to bear me back a again.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I cannot give thee less, to be call'd grateful: Thou thought'st to help me; and such thanks I give As one near death to those that wish him live: But what at full I know, thou know'st no part, I knowing all my peril, thou no art.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: What I can do can do no hurt to try, Since you set up your rest 'gainst remedy. He that of greatest works is finisher Oft does them by the weakest minister: So holy writ in babes hath judgment shown, When judges have been babes; great floods have flown From simple sources, and great seas have dried When miracles have by the greatest been denied. Oft expectation fails and most oft there Where most it promises, and oft it hits Where hope is coldest and despair most fits.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Inspired merit so by breath is barr'd: It is not so with Him that all things knows As 'tis with us that square our guess by shows; But most it is presumption in us when The help of heaven we count the act of men. Dear sir, to my endeavours give consent; Of heaven, not me, make an experiment. I am not an impostor that proclaim Myself against the level of mine aim; But know I think and think I know most sure My art is not past power nor you past cure.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Are thou so confident? within what space Hopest thou my cure?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: The great'st grace lending grace Ere twice the horses of the sun shall bring Their fiery torcher his diurnal ring, Ere twice in murk and occidental damp Moist Hesperus hath quench'd his sleepy lamp, Or four and twenty times the pilot's glass Hath told the thievish minutes how they pass, What is infirm from your sound parts shall fly, Health shall live free and sickness freely die.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Upon thy certainty and confidence What darest thou venture?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Tax of impudence, A strumpet's boldness, a divulged shame Traduced by odious ballads: my maiden's name Sear'd otherwise; nay, worse--if worse--extended With vilest torture let my life be ended.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Methinks in thee some blessed spirit doth speak His powerful sound within an organ weak: And what impossibility would slay In common sense, sense saves another way. Thy life is dear; for all that life can rate Worth name of life in thee hath estimate, Youth, beauty, wisdom, courage, all That happiness and prime can happy call: Thou this to hazard needs must intimate Skill infinite or monstrous desperate. Sweet practiser, thy physic I will try, That ministers thine own death if I die.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: If I break time, or flinch in property Of what I spoke, unpitied let me die, And well deserved: not helping, death's my fee; But, if I help, what do you promise me?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Make thy demand.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: But will you make it even?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Ay, by my sceptre and my hopes of heaven.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Then shalt thou give me with thy kingly hand What husband in thy power I will command: Exempted be from me the arrogance To choose from forth the royal blood of France, My low and humble name to propagate With any branch or image of thy state; But such a one, thy vassal, whom I know Is free for me to ask, thee to bestow.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Here is my hand; the premises observed, Thy will by my performance shall be served: So make the choice of thy own time, for I, Thy resolved patient, on thee still rely. More should I question thee, and more I must, Though more to know could not be more to trust, From whence thou camest, how tended on: but rest Unquestion'd welcome and undoubted blest. Give me some help here, ho! If thou proceed As high as word, my deed shall match thy meed.

scene.title: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Come on, sir; I shall now put you to the height of your breeding.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I will show myself highly fed and lowly taught: I know my business is but to the court.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: To the court! why, what place make you special, when you put off that with such contempt? But to the court!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Truly, madam, if God have lent a man any manners, he may easily put it off at court: he that cannot make a leg, put off's cap, kiss his hand and say nothing, has neither leg, hands, lip, nor cap; and indeed such a fellow, to say precisely, were not for the court; but for me, I have an answer will serve all men.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Marry, that's a bountiful answer that fits all questions.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: It is like a barber's chair that fits all buttocks, the pin-buttock, the quatch-buttock, the brawn buttock, or any buttock.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Will your answer serve fit to all questions?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: As fit as ten groats is for the hand of an attorney, as your French crown for your taffeta punk, as Tib's rush for Tom's forefinger, as a pancake for Shrove Tuesday, a morris for May-day, as the nail to his hole, the cuckold to his horn, as a scolding queen to a wrangling knave, as the nun's lip to the friar's mouth, nay, as the pudding to his skin.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Have you, I say, an answer of such fitness for all questions?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: From below your duke to beneath your constable, it will fit any question.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: It must be an answer of most monstrous size that must fit all demands.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: But a trifle neither, in good faith, if the learned should speak truth of it: here it is, and all that belongs to't. Ask me if I am a courtier: it shall do you no harm to learn.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: To be young again, if we could: I will be a fool in question, hoping to be the wiser by your answer. I pray you, sir, are you a courtier?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: O Lord, sir! There's a simple putting off. More, more, a hundred of them.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Sir, I am a poor friend of yours, that loves you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: O Lord, sir! Thick, thick, spare not me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I think, sir, you can eat none of this homely meat.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: O Lord, sir! Nay, put me to't, I warrant you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: You were lately whipped, sir, as I think.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: O Lord, sir! spare not me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Do you cry, 'O Lord, sir!' at your whipping, and 'spare not me?' Indeed your 'O Lord, sir!' is very sequent to your whipping: you would answer very well to a whipping, if you were but bound to't.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I ne'er had worse luck in my life in my 'O Lord, sir!' I see things may serve long, but not serve ever.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I play the noble housewife with the time To entertain't so merrily with a fool.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: O Lord, sir! why, there't serves well again.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: An end, sir; to your business. Give Helen this, And urge her to a present answer back: Commend me to my kinsmen and my son: This is not much.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Not much commendation to them.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Not much employment for you: you understand me?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Most fruitfully: I am there before my legs.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Haste you again.

scene.title: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: They say miracles are past; and we have our philosophical persons, to make modern and familiar, things supernatural and causeless. Hence is it that we make trifles of terrors, ensconcing ourselves into seeming knowledge, when we should submit ourselves to an unknown fear.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Why, 'tis the rarest argument of wonder that hath shot out in our latter times.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: And so 'tis.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: To be relinquish'd of the artists,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: So I say.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Both of Galen and Paracelsus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: So I say.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Of all the learned and authentic fellows,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Right; so I say.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: That gave him out incurable,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Why, there 'tis; so say I too.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Not to be helped,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Right; as 'twere, a man assured of a--

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Uncertain life, and sure death.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Just, you say well; so would I have said.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I may truly say, it is a novelty to the world.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: It is, indeed: if you will have it in showing, you shall read it in--what do you call there?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: A showing of a heavenly effect in an earthly actor.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: That's it; I would have said the very same.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Why, your dolphin is not lustier: 'fore me, I speak in respect--

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Nay, 'tis strange, 'tis very strange, that is the brief and the tedious of it; and he's of a most facinerious spirit that will not acknowledge it to be the--

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Very hand of heaven.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Ay, so I say.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: In a most weak-- and debile minister, great power, great transcendence: which should, indeed, give us a further use to be made than alone the recovery of the king, as to be-- generally thankful.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I would have said it; you say well. Here comes the king.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Lustig, as the Dutchman says: I'll like a maid the better, whilst I have a tooth in my head: why, he's able to lead her a coranto.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Mort du vinaigre! is not this Helen?

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: 'Fore God, I think so.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Go, call before me all the lords in court. Sit, my preserver, by thy patient's side; And with this healthful hand, whose banish'd sense Thou hast repeal'd, a second time receive The confirmation of my promised gift, Which but attends thy naming. Fair maid, send forth thine eye: this youthful parcel Of noble bachelors stand at my bestowing, O'er whom both sovereign power and father's voice I have to use: thy frank election make; Thou hast power to choose, and they none to forsake.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: To each of you one fair and virtuous mistress Fall, when Love please! marry, to each, but one!

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I'ld give bay Curtal and his furniture, My mouth no more were broken than these boys', And writ as little beard.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Peruse them well: Not one of those but had a noble father.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Gentlemen, Heaven hath through me restored the king to health.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: We understand it, and thank heaven for you.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I am a simple maid, and therein wealthiest, That I protest I simply am a maid. Please it your majesty, I have done already: The blushes in my cheeks thus whisper me, 'We blush that thou shouldst choose; but, be refused, Let the white death sit on thy cheek for ever; We'll ne'er come there again.'

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Make choice; and, see, Who shuns thy love shuns all his love in me.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Now, Dian, from thy altar do I fly, And to imperial Love, that god most high, Do my sighs stream. Sir, will you hear my suit?

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: And grant it.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Thanks, sir; all the rest is mute.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I had rather be in this choice than throw ames-ace for my life.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: The honour, sir, that flames in your fair eyes, Before I speak, too threateningly replies: Love make your fortunes twenty times above Her that so wishes and her humble love!

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: No better, if you please.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: My wish receive, Which great Love grant! and so, I take my leave.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Do all they deny her? An they were sons of mine, I'd have them whipped; or I would send them to the Turk, to make eunuchs of.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Be not afraid that I your hand should take; I'll never do you wrong for your own sake: Blessing upon your vows! and in your bed Find fairer fortune, if you ever wed!

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: These boys are boys of ice, they'll none have her: sure, they are bastards to the English; the French ne'er got 'em.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: You are too young, too happy, and too good, To make yourself a son out of my blood.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Fair one, I think not so.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: There's one grape yet; I am sure thy father drunk wine: but if thou be'st not an ass, I am a youth of fourteen; I have known thee already.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I dare not say I take you; but I give Me and my service, ever whilst I live, Into your guiding power. This is the man.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Why, then, young Bertram, take her; she's thy wife.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: My wife, my liege! I shall beseech your highness, In such a business give me leave to use The help of mine own eyes.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Know'st thou not, Bertram, What she has done for me?

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Yes, my good lord; But never hope to know why I should marry her.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Thou know'st she has raised me from my sickly bed.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: But follows it, my lord, to bring me down Must answer for your raising? I know her well: She had her breeding at my father's charge. A poor physician's daughter my wife! Disdain Rather corrupt me ever!

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: 'Tis only title thou disdain'st in her, the which I can build up. Strange is it that our bloods, Of colour, weight, and heat, pour'd all together, Would quite confound distinction, yet stand off In differences so mighty. If she be All that is virtuous, save what thou dislikest, A poor physician's daughter, thou dislikest Of virtue for the name: but do not so: From lowest place when virtuous things proceed, The place is dignified by the doer's deed: Where great additions swell's, and virtue none, It is a dropsied honour. Good alone Is good without a name. Vileness is so: The property by what it is should go, Not by the title. She is young, wise, fair; In these to nature she's immediate heir, And these breed honour: that is honour's scorn, Which challenges itself as honour's born And is not like the sire: honours thrive, When rather from our acts we them derive Than our foregoers: the mere word's a slave Debosh'd on every tomb, on every grave A lying trophy, and as oft is dumb Where dust and damn'd oblivion is the tomb Of honour'd bones indeed. What should be said? If thou canst like this creature as a maid, I can create the rest: virtue and she Is her own dower; honour and wealth from me.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I cannot love her, nor will strive to do't.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Thou wrong'st thyself, if thou shouldst strive to choose.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: That you are well restored, my lord, I'm glad: Let the rest go.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: My honour's at the stake; which to defeat, I must produce my power. Here, take her hand, Proud scornful boy, unworthy this good gift; That dost in vile misprision shackle up My love and her desert; that canst not dream, We, poising us in her defective scale, Shall weigh thee to the beam; that wilt not know, It is in us to plant thine honour where We please to have it grow. Cheque thy contempt: Obey our will, which travails in thy good: Believe not thy disdain, but presently Do thine own fortunes that obedient right Which both thy duty owes and our power claims; Or I will throw thee from my care for ever Into the staggers and the careless lapse Of youth and ignorance; both my revenge and hate Loosing upon thee, in the name of justice, Without all terms of pity. Speak; thine answer.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Pardon, my gracious lord; for I submit My fancy to your eyes: when I consider What great creation and what dole of honour Flies where you bid it, I find that she, which late Was in my nobler thoughts most base, is now The praised of the king; who, so ennobled, Is as 'twere born so.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Take her by the hand, And tell her she is thine: to whom I promise A counterpoise, if not to thy estate A balance more replete.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I take her hand.

speech.stagedir: Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Good fortune and the favour of the king Smile upon this contract; whose ceremony Shall seem expedient on the now-born brief, And be perform'd to-night: the solemn feast Shall more attend upon the coming space, Expecting absent friends. As thou lovest her, Thy love's to me religious; else, does err.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Do you hear, monsieur? a word with you.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Your pleasure, sir?

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Your lord and master did well to make his recantation.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Recantation! My lord! my master!

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Ay; is it not a language I speak?

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: A most harsh one, and not to be understood without bloody succeeding. My master!

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Are you companion to the Count Rousillon?

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: To any count, to all counts, to what is man.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: To what is count's man: count's master is of another style.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: You are too old, sir; let it satisfy you, you are too old.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I must tell thee, sirrah, I write man; to which title age cannot bring thee.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: What I dare too well do, I dare not do.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I did think thee, for two ordinaries, to be a pretty wise fellow; thou didst make tolerable vent of thy travel; it might pass: yet the scarfs and the bannerets about thee did manifoldly dissuade me from believing thee a vessel of too great a burthen. I have now found thee; when I lose thee again, I care not: yet art thou good for nothing but taking up; and that thou't scarce worth.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Hadst thou not the privilege of antiquity upon thee,--

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Do not plunge thyself too far in anger, lest thou hasten thy trial; which if--Lord have mercy on thee for a hen! So, my good window of lattice, fare thee well: thy casement I need not open, for I look through thee. Give me thy hand.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: My lord, you give me most egregious indignity.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Ay, with all my heart; and thou art worthy of it.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I have not, my lord, deserved it.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Yes, good faith, every dram of it; and I will not bate thee a scruple.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Well, I shall be wiser.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Even as soon as thou canst, for thou hast to pull at a smack o' the contrary. If ever thou be'st bound in thy scarf and beaten, thou shalt find what it is to be proud of thy bondage. I have a desire to hold my acquaintance with thee, or rather my knowledge, that I may say in the default, he is a man I know.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: My lord, you do me most insupportable vexation.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LAFEU and PAROLLES
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I would it were hell-pains for thy sake, and my poor doing eternal: for doing I am past: as I will by thee, in what motion age will give me leave.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Well, thou hast a son shall take this disgrace off me; scurvy, old, filthy, scurvy lord! Well, I must be patient; there is no fettering of authority. I'll beat him, by my life, if I can meet him with any convenience, an he were double and double a lord. I'll have no more pity of his age than I would of--I'll beat him, an if I could but meet him again.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Sirrah, your lord and master's married; there's news for you: you have a new mistress.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I most unfeignedly beseech your lordship to make some reservation of your wrongs: he is my good lord: whom I serve above is my master.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Who? God?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Ay, sir.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: The devil it is that's thy master. Why dost thou garter up thy arms o' this fashion? dost make hose of sleeves? do other servants so? Thou wert best set thy lower part where thy nose stands. By mine honour, if I were but two hours younger, I'ld beat thee: methinks, thou art a general offence, and every man should beat thee: I think thou wast created for men to breathe themselves upon thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: This is hard and undeserved measure, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Go to, sir; you were beaten in Italy for picking a kernel out of a pomegranate; you are a vagabond and no true traveller: you are more saucy with lords and honourable personages than the commission of your birth and virtue gives you heraldry. You are not worth another word, else I'ld call you knave. I leave you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Good, very good; it is so then: good, very good; let it be concealed awhile.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Undone, and forfeited to cares for ever!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: What's the matter, sweet-heart?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Although before the solemn priest I have sworn, I will not bed her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: What, what, sweet-heart?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: O my Parolles, they have married me! I'll to the Tuscan wars, and never bed her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: France is a dog-hole, and it no more merits The tread of a man's foot: to the wars!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: There's letters from my mother: what the import is, I know not yet.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Ay, that would be known. To the wars, my boy, to the wars! He wears his honour in a box unseen, That hugs his kicky-wicky here at home, Spending his manly marrow in her arms, Which should sustain the bound and high curvet Of Mars's fiery steed. To other regions France is a stable; we that dwell in't jades; Therefore, to the war!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: It shall be so: I'll send her to my house, Acquaint my mother with my hate to her, And wherefore I am fled; write to the king That which I durst not speak; his present gift Shall furnish me to those Italian fields, Where noble fellows strike: war is no strife To the dark house and the detested wife.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Will this capriccio hold in thee? art sure?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Go with me to my chamber, and advise me. I'll send her straight away: to-morrow I'll to the wars, she to her single sorrow.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Why, these balls bound; there's noise in it. 'Tis hard: A young man married is a man that's marr'd: Therefore away, and leave her bravely; go: The king has done you wrong: but, hush, 'tis so.

scene.title: SCENE IV. Paris. The KING's palace.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: My mother greets me kindly; is she well?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: She is not well; but yet she has her health: she's very merry; but yet she is not well: but thanks be given, she's very well and wants nothing i', the world; but yet she is not well.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: If she be very well, what does she ail, that she's not very well?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Truly, she's very well indeed, but for two things.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: What two things?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: One, that she's not in heaven, whither God send her quickly! the other that she's in earth, from whence God send her quickly!

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Bless you, my fortunate lady!

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I hope, sir, I have your good will to have mine own good fortunes.
