speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: You had my prayers to lead them on; and to keep them on, have them still. O, my knave, how does my old lady?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: So that you had her wrinkles and I her money, I would she did as you say.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Why, I say nothing.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Marry, you are the wiser man; for many a man's tongue shakes out his master's undoing: to say nothing, to do nothing, to know nothing, and to have nothing, is to be a great part of your title; which is within a very little of nothing.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Away! thou'rt a knave.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: You should have said, sir, before a knave thou'rt a knave; that's, before me thou'rt a knave: this had been truth, sir.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Go to, thou art a witty fool; I have found thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Did you find me in yourself, sir? or were you taught to find me? The search, sir, was profitable; and much fool may you find in you, even to the world's pleasure and the increase of laughter.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Paris. The KING's palace.
SCENE IV. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: What's his will else?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: That you will take your instant leave o' the king And make this haste as your own good proceeding, Strengthen'd with what apology you think May make it probable need.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: What more commands he?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: That, having this obtain'd, you presently Attend his further pleasure.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: In every thing I wait upon his will.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I shall report it so.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I pray you. Come, sirrah.

scene.title: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: But I hope your lordship thinks not him a soldier.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Yes, my lord, and of very valiant approof.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: You have it from his own deliverance.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: And by other warranted testimony.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Then my dial goes not true: I took this lark for a bunting.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I do assure you, my lord, he is very great in knowledge and accordingly valiant.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I have then sinned against his experience and transgressed against his valour; and my state that way is dangerous, since I cannot yet find in my heart to repent. Here he comes: I pray you, make us friends; I will pursue the amity.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: These things shall be done, sir.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Pray you, sir, who's his tailor?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Sir?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: O, I know him well, I, sir; he, sir, 's a good workman, a very good tailor.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Is she gone to the king?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: She is.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Will she away to-night?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: As you'll have her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I have writ my letters, casketed my treasure, Given order for our horses; and to-night, When I should take possession of the bride, End ere I do begin.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: A good traveller is something at the latter end of a dinner; but one that lies three thirds and uses a known truth to pass a thousand nothings with, should be once heard and thrice beaten. God save you, captain.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Is there any unkindness between my lord and you, monsieur?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I know not how I have deserved to run into my lord's displeasure.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: You have made shift to run into 't, boots and spurs and all, like him that leaped into the custard; and out of it you'll run again, rather than suffer question for your residence.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: It may be you have mistaken him, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: And shall do so ever, though I took him at 's prayers. Fare you well, my lord; and believe this of me, there can be no kernel in this light nut; the soul of this man is his clothes. Trust him not in matter of heavy consequence; I have kept of them tame, and know their natures. Farewell, monsieur: I have spoken better of you than you have or will to deserve at my hand; but we must do good against evil.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: An idle lord. I swear.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I think so.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Why, do you not know him?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Yes, I do know him well, and common speech Gives him a worthy pass. Here comes my clog.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I have, sir, as I was commanded from you, Spoke with the king and have procured his leave For present parting; only he desires Some private speech with you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I shall obey his will. You must not marvel, Helen, at my course, Which holds not colour with the time, nor does The ministration and required office On my particular. Prepared I was not For such a business; therefore am I found So much unsettled: this drives me to entreat you That presently you take our way for home; And rather muse than ask why I entreat you, For my respects are better than they seem And my appointments have in them a need Greater than shows itself at the first view To you that know them not. This to my mother: 'Twill be two days ere I shall see you, so I leave you to your wisdom.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Sir, I can nothing say, But that I am your most obedient servant.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Come, come, no more of that.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: And ever shall With true observance seek to eke out that Wherein toward me my homely stars have fail'd To equal my great fortune.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Let that go: My haste is very great: farewell; hie home.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Pray, sir, your pardon.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Well, what would you say?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I am not worthy of the wealth I owe, Nor dare I say 'tis mine, and yet it is; But, like a timorous thief, most fain would steal What law does vouch mine own.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: What would you have?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Something; and scarce so much: nothing, indeed. I would not tell you what I would, my lord: Faith yes; Strangers and foes do sunder, and not kiss.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I pray you, stay not, but in haste to horse.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: I shall not break your bidding, good my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Where are my other men, monsieur? Farewell. Go thou toward home; where I will never come Whilst I can shake my sword or hear the drum. Away, and for our flight.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Paris. The KING's palace.
speech.text: Bravely, coragio!

scene.title: SCENE I. Florence. The DUKE's palace.

speech.stagedir: Flourish. Enter the DUKE of Florence attended; the two Frenchmen, with a troop of soldiers.
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Florence. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: So that from point to point now have you heard The fundamental reasons of this war, Whose great decision hath much blood let forth And more thirsts after.

speech.stagedir: Flourish. Enter the DUKE of Florence attended; the two Frenchmen, with a troop of soldiers.
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Florence. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Holy seems the quarrel Upon your grace's part; black and fearful On the opposer.

speech.stagedir: Flourish. Enter the DUKE of Florence attended; the two Frenchmen, with a troop of soldiers.
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Florence. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Therefore we marvel much our cousin France Would in so just a business shut his bosom Against our borrowing prayers.

speech.stagedir: Flourish. Enter the DUKE of Florence attended; the two Frenchmen, with a troop of soldiers.
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Florence. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Good my lord, The reasons of our state I cannot yield, But like a common and an outward man, That the great figure of a council frames By self-unable motion: therefore dare not Say what I think of it, since I have found Myself in my incertain grounds to fail As often as I guess'd.

speech.stagedir: Flourish. Enter the DUKE of Florence attended; the two Frenchmen, with a troop of soldiers.
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Florence. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Be it his pleasure.

speech.stagedir: Flourish. Enter the DUKE of Florence attended; the two Frenchmen, with a troop of soldiers.
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Florence. The DUKE's palace.
speech.text: But I am sure the younger of our nature, That surfeit on their ease, will day by day Come here for physic.

speech.stagedir: Flourish. Enter the DUKE of Florence attended; the two Frenchmen, with a troop of soldiers.
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Florence. The DUKE's palace.

scene.title: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: It hath happened all as I would have had it, save that he comes not along with her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: By my troth, I take my young lord to be a very melancholy man.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: By what observance, I pray you?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Why, he will look upon his boot and sing; mend the ruff and sing; ask questions and sing; pick his teeth and sing. I know a man that had this trick of melancholy sold a goodly manor for a song.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Let me see what he writes, and when he means to come.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I have no mind to Isbel since I was at court: our old ling and our Isbels o' the country are nothing like your old ling and your Isbels o' the court: the brains of my Cupid's knocked out, and I begin to love, as an old man loves money, with no stomach.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: What have we here?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: E'en that you have there.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I have sent you a daughter-in-law: she hath recovered the king, and undone me. I have wedded her, not bedded her; and sworn to make the 'not' eternal. You shall hear I am run away: know it before the report come. If there be breadth enough in the world, I will hold a long distance. My duty to you. Your unfortunate son, BERTRAM. This is not well, rash and unbridled boy. To fly the favours of so good a king; To pluck his indignation on thy head By the misprising of a maid too virtuous For the contempt of empire.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: O madam, yonder is heavy news within between two soldiers and my young lady!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: What is the matter?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Nay, there is some comfort in the news, some comfort; your son will not be killed so soon as I thought he would.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Why should he be killed?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: So say I, madam, if he run away, as I hear he does: the danger is in standing to't; that's the loss of men, though it be the getting of children. Here they come will tell you more: for my part, I only hear your son was run away.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Save you, good madam.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Madam, my lord is gone, for ever gone.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Do not say so.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Think upon patience. Pray you, gentlemen, I have felt so many quirks of joy and grief, That the first face of neither, on the start, Can woman me unto't: where is my son, I pray you?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Madam, he's gone to serve the duke of Florence: We met him thitherward; for thence we came, And, after some dispatch in hand at court, Thither we bend again.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Look on his letter, madam; here's my passport. When thou canst get the ring upon my finger which never shall come off, and show me a child begotten of thy body that I am father to, then call me husband: but in such a 'then' I write a 'never.' This is a dreadful sentence.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Brought you this letter, gentlemen?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Ay, madam; And for the contents' sake are sorry for our pain.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Ay, madam.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: And to be a soldier?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Such is his noble purpose; and believe 't, The duke will lay upon him all the honour That good convenience claims.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Return you thither?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Ay, madam, with the swiftest wing of speed.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Till I have no wife I have nothing in France. 'Tis bitter.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Find you that there?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Ay, madam.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: 'Tis but the boldness of his hand, haply, which his heart was not consenting to.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Nothing in France, until he have no wife! There's nothing here that is too good for him But only she; and she deserves a lord That twenty such rude boys might tend upon And call her hourly mistress. Who was with him?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: A servant only, and a gentleman Which I have sometime known.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Parolles, was it not?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Ay, my good lady, he.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: A very tainted fellow, and full of wickedness. My son corrupts a well-derived nature With his inducement.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Indeed, good lady, The fellow has a deal of that too much, Which holds him much to have.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: You're welcome, gentlemen. I will entreat you, when you see my son, To tell him that his sword can never win The honour that he loses: more I'll entreat you Written to bear along.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: We serve you, madam, In that and all your worthiest affairs.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Not so, but as we change our courtesies. Will you draw near!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: 'Till I have no wife, I have nothing in France.' Nothing in France, until he has no wife! Thou shalt have none, Rousillon, none in France; Then hast thou all again. Poor lord! is't I That chase thee from thy country and expose Those tender limbs of thine to the event Of the none-sparing war? and is it I That drive thee from the sportive court, where thou Wast shot at with fair eyes, to be the mark Of smoky muskets? O you leaden messengers, That ride upon the violent speed of fire, Fly with false aim; move the still-peering air, That sings with piercing; do not touch my lord. Whoever shoots at him, I set him there; Whoever charges on his forward breast, I am the caitiff that do hold him to't; And, though I kill him not, I am the cause His death was so effected: better 'twere I met the ravin lion when he roar'd With sharp constraint of hunger; better 'twere That all the miseries which nature owes Were mine at once. No, come thou home, Rousillon, Whence honour but of danger wins a scar, As oft it loses all: I will be gone; My being here it is that holds thee hence: Shall I stay here to do't? no, no, although The air of paradise did fan the house And angels officed all: I will be gone, That pitiful rumour may report my flight, To consolate thine ear. Come, night; end, day! For with the dark, poor thief, I'll steal away.

scene.title: SCENE III. Florence. Before the DUKE's palace.

speech.stagedir: Flourish. Enter the DUKE of Florence, BERTRAM, PAROLLES, Soldiers, Drum, and Trumpets
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Florence. Before the DUKE's palace.
speech.text: The general of our horse thou art; and we, Great in our hope, lay our best love and credence Upon thy promising fortune.

speech.stagedir: Flourish. Enter the DUKE of Florence, BERTRAM, PAROLLES, Soldiers, Drum, and Trumpets
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Florence. Before the DUKE's palace.
speech.text: Sir, it is A charge too heavy for my strength, but yet We'll strive to bear it for your worthy sake To the extreme edge of hazard.

speech.stagedir: Flourish. Enter the DUKE of Florence, BERTRAM, PAROLLES, Soldiers, Drum, and Trumpets
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Florence. Before the DUKE's palace.

speech.stagedir: Flourish. Enter the DUKE of Florence, BERTRAM, PAROLLES, Soldiers, Drum, and Trumpets
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Florence. Before the DUKE's palace.
speech.text: This very day, Great Mars, I put myself into thy file: Make me but like my thoughts, and I shall prove A lover of thy drum, hater of love.

scene.title: SCENE IV. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Alas! and would you take the letter of her? Might you not know she would do as she has done, By sending me a letter? Read it again.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I am Saint Jaques' pilgrim, thither gone: Ambitious love hath so in me offended, That barefoot plod I the cold ground upon, With sainted vow my faults to have amended. Write, write, that from the bloody course of war My dearest master, your dear son, may hie: Bless him at home in peace, whilst I from far His name with zealous fervor sanctify: His taken labours bid him me forgive; I, his despiteful Juno, sent him forth From courtly friends, with camping foes to live, Where death and danger dogs the heels of worth: He is too good and fair for death and me: Whom I myself embrace, to set him free.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Ah, what sharp stings are in her mildest words! Rinaldo, you did never lack advice so much, As letting her pass so: had I spoke with her, I could have well diverted her intents, Which thus she hath prevented.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Pardon me, madam: If I had given you this at over-night, She might have been o'erta'en; and yet she writes, Pursuit would be but vain.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: What angel shall Bless this unworthy husband? he cannot thrive, Unless her prayers, whom heaven delights to hear And loves to grant, reprieve him from the wrath Of greatest justice. Write, write, Rinaldo, To this unworthy husband of his wife; Let every word weigh heavy of her worth That he does weigh too light: my greatest grief. Though little he do feel it, set down sharply. Dispatch the most convenient messenger: When haply he shall hear that she is gone, He will return; and hope I may that she, Hearing so much, will speed her foot again, Led hither by pure love: which of them both Is dearest to me. I have no skill in sense To make distinction: provide this messenger: My heart is heavy and mine age is weak; Grief would have tears, and sorrow bids me speak.

scene.title: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: Nay, come; for if they do approach the city, we shall lose all the sight.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: They say the French count has done most honourable service.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: It is reported that he has taken their greatest commander; and that with his own hand he slew the duke's brother. We have lost our labour; they are gone a contrary way: hark! you may know by their trumpets.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: Come, let's return again, and suffice ourselves with the report of it. Well, Diana, take heed of this French earl: the honour of a maid is her name; and no legacy is so rich as honesty.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: I have told my neighbour how you have been solicited by a gentleman his companion.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: I know that knave; hang him! one Parolles: a filthy officer he is in those suggestions for the young earl. Beware of them, Diana; their promises, enticements, oaths, tokens, and all these engines of lust, are not the things they go under: many a maid hath been seduced by them; and the misery is, example, that so terrible shows in the wreck of maidenhood, cannot for all that dissuade succession, but that they are limed with the twigs that threaten them. I hope I need not to advise you further; but I hope your own grace will keep you where you are, though there were no further danger known but the modesty which is so lost.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: You shall not need to fear me.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: I hope so. Look, here comes a pilgrim: I know she will lie at my house; thither they send one another: I'll question her. God save you, pilgrim! whither are you bound?

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: To Saint Jaques le Grand. Where do the palmers lodge, I do beseech you?

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: At the Saint Francis here beside the port.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: Is this the way?

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: Ay, marry, is't. Hark you! they come this way. If you will tarry, holy pilgrim, But till the troops come by, I will conduct you where you shall be lodged; The rather, for I think I know your hostess As ample as myself.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: Is it yourself?

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: If you shall please so, pilgrim.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: I thank you, and will stay upon your leisure.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: You came, I think, from France?

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: I did so.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: Here you shall see a countryman of yours That has done worthy service.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: His name, I pray you.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: The Count Rousillon: know you such a one?

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: But by the ear, that hears most nobly of him: His face I know not.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: Whatsome'er he is, He's bravely taken here. He stole from France, As 'tis reported, for the king had married him Against his liking: think you it is so?

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: Ay, surely, mere the truth: I know his lady.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: There is a gentleman that serves the count Reports but coarsely of her.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: What's his name?

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: Monsieur Parolles.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: O, I believe with him, In argument of praise, or to the worth Of the great count himself, she is too mean To have her name repeated: all her deserving Is a reserved honesty, and that I have not heard examined.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: Alas, poor lady! 'Tis a hard bondage to become the wife Of a detesting lord.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: I warrant, good creature, wheresoe'er she is, Her heart weighs sadly: this young maid might do her A shrewd turn, if she pleased.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: How do you mean? May be the amorous count solicits her In the unlawful purpose.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: He does indeed; And brokes with all that can in such a suit Corrupt the tender honour of a maid: But she is arm'd for him and keeps her guard In honestest defence.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: The gods forbid else!

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: Which is the Frenchman?

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: He; That with the plume: 'tis a most gallant fellow. I would he loved his wife: if he were honester He were much goodlier: is't not a handsome gentleman?

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: I like him well.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: 'Tis pity he is not honest: yond's that same knave That leads him to these places: were I his lady, I would Poison that vile rascal.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: Which is he?

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: That jack-an-apes with scarfs: why is he melancholy?

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: Perchance he's hurt i' the battle.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: Lose our drum! well.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: He's shrewdly vexed at something: look, he has spied us.

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: Marry, hang you!

speech.stagedir: Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA, and MARIANA, with other Citizens
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: And your courtesy, for a ring-carrier!

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: The troop is past. Come, pilgrim, I will bring you Where you shall host: of enjoin'd penitents There's four or five, to great Saint Jaques bound, Already at my house.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: I humbly thank you: Please it this matron and this gentle maid To eat with us to-night, the charge and thanking Shall be for me; and, to requite you further, I will bestow some precepts of this virgin Worthy the note.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Florence. Without the walls. A tucket afar off.
speech.text: We'll take your offer kindly.

scene.title: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM and the two French Lords
speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: Nay, good my lord, put him to't; let him have his way.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM and the two French Lords
speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: If your lordship find him not a hilding, hold me no more in your respect.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM and the two French Lords
speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: On my life, my lord, a bubble.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM and the two French Lords
speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: Do you think I am so far deceived in him?

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM and the two French Lords
speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: Believe it, my lord, in mine own direct knowledge, without any malice, but to speak of him as my kinsman, he's a most notable coward, an infinite and endless liar, an hourly promise-breaker, the owner of no one good quality worthy your lordship's entertainment.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM and the two French Lords
speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: It were fit you knew him; lest, reposing too far in his virtue, which he hath not, he might at some great and trusty business in a main danger fail you.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM and the two French Lords
speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: I would I knew in what particular action to try him.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM and the two French Lords
speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: None better than to let him fetch off his drum, which you hear him so confidently undertake to do.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM and the two French Lords
speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: I, with a troop of Florentines, will suddenly surprise him; such I will have, whom I am sure he knows not from the enemy: we will bind and hoodwink him so, that he shall suppose no other but that he is carried into the leaguer of the adversaries, when we bring him to our own tents. Be but your lordship present at his examination: if he do not, for the promise of his life and in the highest compulsion of base fear, offer to betray you and deliver all the intelligence in his power against you, and that with the divine forfeit of his soul upon oath, never trust my judgment in any thing.

speech.stagedir: Enter BERTRAM and the two French Lords
speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: O, for the love of laughter, let him fetch his drum; he says he has a stratagem for't: when your lordship sees the bottom of his success in't, and to what metal this counterfeit lump of ore will be melted, if you give him not John Drum's entertainment, your inclining cannot be removed. Here he comes.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: O, for the love of laughter, hinder not the honour of his design: let him fetch off his drum in any hand.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: How now, monsieur! this drum sticks sorely in your disposition.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: A pox on't, let it go; 'tis but a drum.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: 'But a drum'! is't 'but a drum'? A drum so lost! There was excellent command,--to charge in with our horse upon our own wings, and to rend our own soldiers!

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: That was not to be blamed in the command of the service: it was a disaster of war that Caesar himself could not have prevented, if he had been there to command.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: Well, we cannot greatly condemn our success: some dishonour we had in the loss of that drum; but it is not to be recovered.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: It might have been recovered.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: It might; but it is not now.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: It is to be recovered: but that the merit of service is seldom attributed to the true and exact performer, I would have that drum or another, or 'hic jacet.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: Why, if you have a stomach, to't, monsieur: if you think your mystery in stratagem can bring this instrument of honour again into his native quarter, be magnanimous in the enterprise and go on; I will grace the attempt for a worthy exploit: if you speed well in it, the duke shall both speak of it. and extend to you what further becomes his greatness, even to the utmost syllable of your worthiness.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: By the hand of a soldier, I will undertake it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: But you must not now slumber in it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: I'll about it this evening: and I will presently pen down my dilemmas, encourage myself in my certainty, put myself into my mortal preparation; and by midnight look to hear further from me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: May I be bold to acquaint his grace you are gone about it?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: I know not what the success will be, my lord; but the attempt I vow.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: I know thou'rt valiant; and, to the possibility of thy soldiership, will subscribe for thee. Farewell.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: I love not many words.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: No more than a fish loves water. Is not this a strange fellow, my lord, that so confidently seems to undertake this business, which he knows is not to be done; damns himself to do and dares better be damned than to do't?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: You do not know him, my lord, as we do: certain it is that he will steal himself into a man's favour and for a week escape a great deal of discoveries; but when you find him out, you have him ever after.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: Why, do you think he will make no deed at all of this that so seriously he does address himself unto?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: None in the world; but return with an invention and clap upon you two or three probable lies: but we have almost embossed him; you shall see his fall to-night; for indeed he is not for your lordship's respect.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: We'll make you some sport with the fox ere we case him. He was first smoked by the old lord Lafeu: when his disguise and he is parted, tell me what a sprat you shall find him; which you shall see this very night.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: I must go look my twigs: he shall be caught.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: Your brother he shall go along with me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: As't please your lordship: I'll leave you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: Now will I lead you to the house, and show you The lass I spoke of.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: But you say she's honest.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: That's all the fault: I spoke with her but once And found her wondrous cold; but I sent to her, By this same coxcomb that we have i' the wind, Tokens and letters which she did re-send; And this is all I have done. She's a fair creature: Will you go see her?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.
speech.text: With all my heart, my lord.

scene.title: SCENE VII. Florence. The Widow's house.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: If you misdoubt me that I am not she, I know not how I shall assure you further, But I shall lose the grounds I work upon.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: Though my estate be fallen, I was well born, Nothing acquainted with these businesses; And would not put my reputation now In any staining act.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: Nor would I wish you. First, give me trust, the count he is my husband, And what to your sworn counsel I have spoken Is so from word to word; and then you cannot, By the good aid that I of you shall borrow, Err in bestowing it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: I should believe you: For you have show'd me that which well approves You're great in fortune.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: Take this purse of gold, And let me buy your friendly help thus far, Which I will over-pay and pay again When I have found it. The count he wooes your daughter, Lays down his wanton siege before her beauty, Resolved to carry her: let her in fine consent, As we'll direct her how 'tis best to bear it. Now his important blood will nought deny That she'll demand: a ring the county wears, That downward hath succeeded in his house From son to son, some four or five descents Since the first father wore it: this ring he holds In most rich choice; yet in his idle fire, To buy his will, it would not seem too dear, Howe'er repented after.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: Now I see The bottom of your purpose.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: You see it lawful, then: it is no more, But that your daughter, ere she seems as won, Desires this ring; appoints him an encounter; In fine, delivers me to fill the time, Herself most chastely absent: after this, To marry her, I'll add three thousand crowns To what is passed already.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: I have yielded: Instruct my daughter how she shall persever, That time and place with this deceit so lawful May prove coherent. Every night he comes With musics of all sorts and songs composed To her unworthiness: it nothing steads us To chide him from our eaves; for he persists As if his life lay on't.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: Why then to-night Let us assay our plot; which, if it speed, Is wicked meaning in a lawful deed And lawful meaning in a lawful act, Where both not sin, and yet a sinful fact: But let's about it.

scene.title: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.

speech.stagedir: Enter Second French Lord, with five or six other Soldiers in ambush
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: He can come no other way but by this hedge-corner. When you sally upon him, speak what terrible language you will: though you understand it not yourselves, no matter; for we must not seem to understand him, unless some one among us whom we must produce for an interpreter.

speech.stagedir: Enter Second French Lord, with five or six other Soldiers in ambush
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: Good captain, let me be the interpreter.

speech.stagedir: Enter Second French Lord, with five or six other Soldiers in ambush
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: Art not acquainted with him? knows he not thy voice?

speech.stagedir: Enter Second French Lord, with five or six other Soldiers in ambush
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: No, sir, I warrant you.

speech.stagedir: Enter Second French Lord, with five or six other Soldiers in ambush
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: But what linsey-woolsey hast thou to speak to us again?

speech.stagedir: Enter Second French Lord, with five or six other Soldiers in ambush
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: E'en such as you speak to me.

speech.stagedir: Enter Second French Lord, with five or six other Soldiers in ambush
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: He must think us some band of strangers i' the adversary's entertainment. Now he hath a smack of all neighbouring languages; therefore we must every one be a man of his own fancy, not to know what we speak one to another; so we seem to know, is to know straight our purpose: choughs' language, gabble enough, and good enough. As for you, interpreter, you must seem very politic. But couch, ho! here he comes, to beguile two hours in a sleep, and then to return and swear the lies he forges.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: Ten o'clock: within these three hours 'twill be time enough to go home. What shall I say I have done? It must be a very plausive invention that carries it: they begin to smoke me; and disgraces have of late knocked too often at my door. I find my tongue is too foolhardy; but my heart hath the fear of Mars before it and of his creatures, not daring the reports of my tongue.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: This is the first truth that e'er thine own tongue was guilty of.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: What the devil should move me to undertake the recovery of this drum, being not ignorant of the impossibility, and knowing I had no such purpose? I must give myself some hurts, and say I got them in exploit: yet slight ones will not carry it; they will say, 'Came you off with so little?' and great ones I dare not give. Wherefore, what's the instance? Tongue, I must put you into a butter-woman's mouth and buy myself another of Bajazet's mule, if you prattle me into these perils.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: Is it possible he should know what he is, and be that he is?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: I would the cutting of my garments would serve the turn, or the breaking of my Spanish sword.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: We cannot afford you so.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: Or the baring of my beard; and to say it was in stratagem.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: 'Twould not do.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: Or to drown my clothes, and say I was stripped.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: Hardly serve.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: Though I swore I leaped from the window of the citadel.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: How deep?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: Thirty fathom.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: Three great oaths would scarce make that be believed.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: I would I had any drum of the enemy's: I would swear I recovered it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: You shall hear one anon.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: A drum now of the enemy's,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: Throca movousus, cargo, cargo, cargo.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: Cargo, cargo, cargo, villiando par corbo, cargo.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: O, ransom, ransom! do not hide mine eyes.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: Boskos thromuldo boskos.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: I know you are the Muskos' regiment: And I shall lose my life for want of language; If there be here German, or Dane, low Dutch, Italian, or French, let him speak to me; I'll Discover that which shall undo the Florentine.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: Boskos vauvado: I understand thee, and can speak thy tongue. Kerely bonto, sir, betake thee to thy faith, for seventeen poniards are at thy bosom.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: O!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: O, pray, pray, pray! Manka revania dulche.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: Oscorbidulchos volivorco.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: The general is content to spare thee yet; And, hoodwink'd as thou art, will lead thee on To gather from thee: haply thou mayst inform Something to save thy life.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: O, let me live! And all the secrets of our camp I'll show, Their force, their purposes; nay, I'll speak that Which you will wonder at.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: But wilt thou faithfully?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: If I do not, damn me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: Acordo linta. Come on; thou art granted space.

speech.stagedir: Exit, with PAROLLES guarded. A short alarum within
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: Go, tell the Count Rousillon, and my brother, We have caught the woodcock, and will keep him muffled Till we do hear from them.

speech.stagedir: Exit, with PAROLLES guarded. A short alarum within
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: Captain, I will.

speech.stagedir: Exit, with PAROLLES guarded. A short alarum within
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: A' will betray us all unto ourselves: Inform on that.

speech.stagedir: Exit, with PAROLLES guarded. A short alarum within
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: So I will, sir.

speech.stagedir: Exit, with PAROLLES guarded. A short alarum within
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.
speech.text: Till then I'll keep him dark and safely lock'd.

scene.title: SCENE II. Florence. The Widow's house.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: They told me that your name was Fontibell.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: No, my good lord, Diana.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: Titled goddess; And worth it, with addition! But, fair soul, In your fine frame hath love no quality? If quick fire of youth light not your mind, You are no maiden, but a monument: When you are dead, you should be such a one As you are now, for you are cold and stem; And now you should be as your mother was When your sweet self was got.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: She then was honest.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: So should you be.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: No: My mother did but duty; such, my lord, As you owe to your wife.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: No more o' that; I prithee, do not strive against my vows: I was compell'd to her; but I love thee By love's own sweet constraint, and will for ever Do thee all rights of service.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: Ay, so you serve us Till we serve you; but when you have our roses, You barely leave our thorns to prick ourselves And mock us with our bareness.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: How have I sworn!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: 'Tis not the many oaths that makes the truth, But the plain single vow that is vow'd true. What is not holy, that we swear not by, But take the High'st to witness: then, pray you, tell me, If I should swear by God's great attributes, I loved you dearly, would you believe my oaths, When I did love you ill? This has no holding, To swear by him whom I protest to love, That I will work against him: therefore your oaths Are words and poor conditions, but unseal'd, At least in my opinion.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: Change it, change it; Be not so holy-cruel: love is holy; And my integrity ne'er knew the crafts That you do charge men with. Stand no more off, But give thyself unto my sick desires, Who then recover: say thou art mine, and ever My love as it begins shall so persever.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: I see that men make ropes in such a scarre That we'll forsake ourselves. Give me that ring.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: I'll lend it thee, my dear; but have no power To give it from me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: Will you not, my lord?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: It is an honour 'longing to our house, Bequeathed down from many ancestors; Which were the greatest obloquy i' the world In me to lose.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: Mine honour's such a ring: My chastity's the jewel of our house, Bequeathed down from many ancestors; Which were the greatest obloquy i' the world In me to lose: thus your own proper wisdom Brings in the champion Honour on my part, Against your vain assault.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: Here, take my ring: My house, mine honour, yea, my life, be thine, And I'll be bid by thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: When midnight comes, knock at my chamber-window: I'll order take my mother shall not hear. Now will I charge you in the band of truth, When you have conquer'd my yet maiden bed, Remain there but an hour, nor speak to me: My reasons are most strong; and you shall know them When back again this ring shall be deliver'd: And on your finger in the night I'll put Another ring, that what in time proceeds May token to the future our past deeds. Adieu, till then; then, fail not. You have won A wife of me, though there my hope be done.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: A heaven on earth I have won by wooing thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: For which live long to thank both heaven and me! You may so in the end. My mother told me just how he would woo, As if she sat in 's heart; she says all men Have the like oaths: he had sworn to marry me When his wife's dead; therefore I'll lie with him When I am buried. Since Frenchmen are so braid, Marry that will, I live and die a maid: Only in this disguise I think't no sin To cozen him that would unjustly win.

scene.title: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: You have not given him his mother's letter?

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: I have delivered it an hour since: there is something in't that stings his nature; for on the reading it he changed almost into another man.

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: He has much worthy blame laid upon him for shaking off so good a wife and so sweet a lady.

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Especially he hath incurred the everlasting displeasure of the king, who had even tuned his bounty to sing happiness to him. I will tell you a thing, but you shall let it dwell darkly with you.

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: When you have spoken it, 'tis dead, and I am the grave of it.

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: He hath perverted a young gentlewoman here in Florence, of a most chaste renown; and this night he fleshes his will in the spoil of her honour: he hath given her his monumental ring, and thinks himself made in the unchaste composition.

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Now, God delay our rebellion! as we are ourselves, what things are we!

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Merely our own traitors. And as in the common course of all treasons, we still see them reveal themselves, till they attain to their abhorred ends, so he that in this action contrives against his own nobility, in his proper stream o'erflows himself.

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Is it not meant damnable in us, to be trumpeters of our unlawful intents? We shall not then have his company to-night?

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Not till after midnight; for he is dieted to his hour.

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: That approaches apace; I would gladly have him see his company anatomized, that he might take a measure of his own judgments, wherein so curiously he had set this counterfeit.

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: We will not meddle with him till he come; for his presence must be the whip of the other.

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: In the mean time, what hear you of these wars?

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: I hear there is an overture of peace.

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Nay, I assure you, a peace concluded.

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: What will Count Rousillon do then? will he travel higher, or return again into France?

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: I perceive, by this demand, you are not altogether of his council.

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Let it be forbid, sir; so should I be a great deal of his act.

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Sir, his wife some two months since fled from his house: her pretence is a pilgrimage to Saint Jaques le Grand; which holy undertaking with most austere sanctimony she accomplished; and, there residing the tenderness of her nature became as a prey to her grief; in fine, made a groan of her last breath, and now she sings in heaven.

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: How is this justified?

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: The stronger part of it by her own letters, which makes her story true, even to the point of her death: her death itself, which could not be her office to say is come, was faithfully confirmed by the rector of the place.

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Hath the count all this intelligence?

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Ay, and the particular confirmations, point from point, so to the full arming of the verity.

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: I am heartily sorry that he'll be glad of this.

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: How mightily sometimes we make us comforts of our losses!

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: And how mightily some other times we drown our gain in tears! The great dignity that his valour hath here acquired for him shall at home be encountered with a shame as ample.

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: The web of our life is of a mingled yarn, good and ill together: our virtues would be proud, if our faults whipped them not; and our crimes would despair, if they were not cherished by our virtues. How now! where's your master?

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: He met the duke in the street, sir, of whom he hath taken a solemn leave: his lordship will next morning for France. The duke hath offered him letters of commendations to the king.

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: They shall be no more than needful there, if they were more than they can commend.

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: They cannot be too sweet for the king's tartness. Here's his lordship now. How now, my lord! is't not after midnight?

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: I have to-night dispatched sixteen businesses, a month's length a-piece, by an abstract of success: I have congied with the duke, done my adieu with his nearest; buried a wife, mourned for her; writ to my lady mother I am returning; entertained my convoy; and between these main parcels of dispatch effected many nicer needs; the last was the greatest, but that I have not ended yet.

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: If the business be of any difficulty, and this morning your departure hence, it requires haste of your lordship.

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: I mean, the business is not ended, as fearing to hear of it hereafter. But shall we have this dialogue between the fool and the soldier? Come, bring forth this counterfeit module, he has deceived me, like a double-meaning prophesier.

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Bring him forth: has sat i' the stocks all night, poor gallant knave.

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: No matter: his heels have deserved it, in usurping his spurs so long. How does he carry himself?

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: I have told your lordship already, the stocks carry him. But to answer you as you would be understood; he weeps like a wench that had shed her milk: he hath confessed himself to Morgan, whom he supposes to be a friar, from the time of his remembrance to this very instant disaster of his setting i' the stocks: and what think you he hath confessed?

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Nothing of me, has a'?

speech.stagedir: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: His confession is taken, and it shall be read to his face: if your lordship be in't, as I believe you are, you must have the patience to hear it.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: A plague upon him! muffled! he can say nothing of me: hush, hush!

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Hoodman comes! Portotartarosa

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: He calls for the tortures: what will you say without 'em?

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: I will confess what I know without constraint: if ye pinch me like a pasty, I can say no more.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Bosko chimurcho.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Boblibindo chicurmurco.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: You are a merciful general. Our general bids you answer to what I shall ask you out of a note.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: And truly, as I hope to live.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: 'First demand of him how many horse the duke is strong.' What say you to that?

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Five or six thousand; but very weak and unserviceable: the troops are all scattered, and the commanders very poor rogues, upon my reputation and credit and as I hope to live.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Shall I set down your answer so?

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Do: I'll take the sacrament on't, how and which way you will.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: All's one to him. What a past-saving slave is this!

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: You're deceived, my lord: this is Monsieur Parolles, the gallant militarist,--that was his own phrase,--that had the whole theoric of war in the knot of his scarf, and the practise in the chape of his dagger.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: I will never trust a man again for keeping his sword clean. nor believe he can have every thing in him by wearing his apparel neatly.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Well, that's set down.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Five or six thousand horse, I said,-- I will say true,--or thereabouts, set down, for I'll speak truth.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: He's very near the truth in this.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: But I con him no thanks for't, in the nature he delivers it.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Poor rogues, I pray you, say.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Well, that's set down.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: I humbly thank you, sir: a truth's a truth, the rogues are marvellous poor.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: 'Demand of him, of what strength they are a-foot.' What say you to that?

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: By my troth, sir, if I were to live this present hour, I will tell true. Let me see: Spurio, a hundred and fifty; Sebastian, so many; Corambus, so many; Jaques, so many; Guiltian, Cosmo, Lodowick, and Gratii, two hundred and fifty each; mine own company, Chitopher, Vaumond, Bentii, two hundred and fifty each: so that the muster-file, rotten and sound, upon my life, amounts not to fifteen thousand poll; half of the which dare not shake snow from off their cassocks, lest they shake themselves to pieces.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: What shall be done to him?

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Nothing, but let him have thanks. Demand of him my condition, and what credit I have with the duke.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Well, that's set down. 'You shall demand of him, whether one Captain Dumain be i' the camp, a Frenchman; what his reputation is with the duke; what his valour, honesty, and expertness in wars; or whether he thinks it were not possible, with well-weighing sums of gold, to corrupt him to revolt.' What say you to this? what do you know of it?

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: I beseech you, let me answer to the particular of the inter'gatories: demand them singly.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Do you know this Captain Dumain?

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: I know him: a' was a botcher's 'prentice in Paris, from whence he was whipped for getting the shrieve's fool with child,--a dumb innocent, that could not say him nay.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Nay, by your leave, hold your hands; though I know his brains are forfeit to the next tile that falls.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Well, is this captain in the duke of Florence's camp?

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Upon my knowledge, he is, and lousy.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Nay look not so upon me; we shall hear of your lordship anon.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: What is his reputation with the duke?

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: The duke knows him for no other but a poor officer of mine; and writ to me this other day to turn him out o' the band: I think I have his letter in my pocket.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Marry, we'll search.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: In good sadness, I do not know; either it is there, or it is upon a file with the duke's other letters in my tent.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Here 'tis; here's a paper: shall I read it to you?

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: I do not know if it be it or no.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Our interpreter does it well.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Excellently.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: 'Dian, the count's a fool, and full of gold,'--

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: That is not the duke's letter, sir; that is an advertisement to a proper maid in Florence, one Diana, to take heed of the allurement of one Count Rousillon, a foolish idle boy, but for all that very ruttish: I pray you, sir, put it up again.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Nay, I'll read it first, by your favour.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: My meaning in't, I protest, was very honest in the behalf of the maid; for I knew the young count to be a dangerous and lascivious boy, who is a whale to virginity and devours up all the fry it finds.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Damnable both-sides rogue!

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: He shall be whipped through the army with this rhyme in's forehead.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: This is your devoted friend, sir, the manifold linguist and the armipotent soldier.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: I could endure any thing before but a cat, and now he's a cat to me.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: I perceive, sir, by the general's looks, we shall be fain to hang you.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: My life, sir, in any case: not that I am afraid to die; but that, my offences being many, I would repent out the remainder of nature: let me live, sir, in a dungeon, i' the stocks, or any where, so I may live.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: We'll see what may be done, so you confess freely; therefore, once more to this Captain Dumain: you have answered to his reputation with the duke and to his valour: what is his honesty?

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: He will steal, sir, an egg out of a cloister: for rapes and ravishments he parallels Nessus: he professes not keeping of oaths; in breaking 'em he is stronger than Hercules: he will lie, sir, with such volubility, that you would think truth were a fool: drunkenness is his best virtue, for he will be swine-drunk; and in his sleep he does little harm, save to his bed-clothes about him; but they know his conditions and lay him in straw. I have but little more to say, sir, of his honesty: he has every thing that an honest man should not have; what an honest man should have, he has nothing.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: I begin to love him for this.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: For this description of thine honesty? A pox upon him for me, he's more and more a cat.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
