speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: What say you to his expertness in war?

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Faith, sir, he has led the drum before the English tragedians; to belie him, I will not, and more of his soldiership I know not; except, in that country he had the honour to be the officer at a place there called Mile-end, to instruct for the doubling of files: I would do the man what honour I can, but of this I am not certain.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: He hath out-villained villany so far, that the rarity redeems him.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: A pox on him, he's a cat still.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: His qualities being at this poor price, I need not to ask you if gold will corrupt him to revolt.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Sir, for a quart d'ecu he will sell the fee-simple of his salvation, the inheritance of it; and cut the entail from all remainders, and a perpetual succession for it perpetually.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: What's his brother, the other Captain Dumain?

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Why does be ask him of me?

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: What's he?

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: E'en a crow o' the same nest; not altogether so great as the first in goodness, but greater a great deal in evil: he excels his brother for a coward, yet his brother is reputed one of the best that is: in a retreat he outruns any lackey; marry, in coming on he has the cramp.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: If your life be saved, will you undertake to betray the Florentine?

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Ay, and the captain of his horse, Count Rousillon.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: I'll whisper with the general, and know his pleasure.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: I'll no more drumming; a plague of all drums! Only to seem to deserve well, and to beguile the supposition of that lascivious young boy the count, have I run into this danger. Yet who would have suspected an ambush where I was taken?

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: There is no remedy, sir, but you must die: the general says, you that have so traitorously discovered the secrets of your army and made such pestiferous reports of men very nobly held, can serve the world for no honest use; therefore you must die. Come, headsman, off with his head.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: O Lord, sir, let me live, or let me see my death!

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: That shall you, and take your leave of all your friends. So, look about you: know you any here?

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Good morrow, noble captain.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: God bless you, Captain Parolles.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: God save you, noble captain.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Captain, what greeting will you to my Lord Lafeu? I am for France.

speech.stagedir: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Good captain, will you give me a copy of the sonnet you writ to Diana in behalf of the Count Rousillon? an I were not a very coward, I'ld compel it of you: but fare you well.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: You are undone, captain, all but your scarf; that has a knot on't yet

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Who cannot be crushed with a plot?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: If you could find out a country where but women were that had received so much shame, you might begin an impudent nation. Fare ye well, sir; I am for France too: we shall speak of you there.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.
speech.text: Yet am I thankful: if my heart were great, 'Twould burst at this. Captain I'll be no more; But I will eat and drink, and sleep as soft As captain shall: simply the thing I am Shall make me live. Who knows himself a braggart, Let him fear this, for it will come to pass that every braggart shall be found an ass. Rust, sword? cool, blushes! and, Parolles, live Safest in shame! being fool'd, by foolery thrive! There's place and means for every man alive. I'll after them.

scene.title: SCENE IV. Florence. The Widow's house.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: That you may well perceive I have not wrong'd you, One of the greatest in the Christian world Shall be my surety; 'fore whose throne 'tis needful, Ere I can perfect mine intents, to kneel: Time was, I did him a desired office, Dear almost as his life; which gratitude Through flinty Tartar's bosom would peep forth, And answer, thanks: I duly am inform'd His grace is at Marseilles; to which place We have convenient convoy. You must know I am supposed dead: the army breaking, My husband hies him home; where, heaven aiding, And by the leave of my good lord the king, We'll be before our welcome.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: Gentle madam, You never had a servant to whose trust Your business was more welcome.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: Nor you, mistress, Ever a friend whose thoughts more truly labour To recompense your love: doubt not but heaven Hath brought me up to be your daughter's dower, As it hath fated her to be my motive And helper to a husband. But, O strange men! That can such sweet use make of what they hate, When saucy trusting of the cozen'd thoughts Defiles the pitchy night: so lust doth play With what it loathes for that which is away. But more of this hereafter. You, Diana, Under my poor instructions yet must suffer Something in my behalf.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: Let death and honesty Go with your impositions, I am yours Upon your will to suffer.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Florence. The Widow's house.
speech.text: Yet, I pray you: But with the word the time will bring on summer, When briers shall have leaves as well as thorns, And be as sweet as sharp. We must away; Our wagon is prepared, and time revives us: All's well that ends well; still the fine's the crown; Whate'er the course, the end is the renown.

scene.title: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: No, no, no, your son was misled with a snipt-taffeta fellow there, whose villanous saffron would have made all the unbaked and doughy youth of a nation in his colour: your daughter-in-law had been alive at this hour, and your son here at home, more advanced by the king than by that red-tailed humble-bee I speak of.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I would I had not known him; it was the death of the most virtuous gentlewoman that ever nature had praise for creating. If she had partaken of my flesh, and cost me the dearest groans of a mother, I could not have owed her a more rooted love.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: 'Twas a good lady, 'twas a good lady: we may pick a thousand salads ere we light on such another herb.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Indeed, sir, she was the sweet marjoram of the salad, or rather, the herb of grace.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: They are not herbs, you knave; they are nose-herbs.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I am no great Nebuchadnezzar, sir; I have not much skill in grass.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Whether dost thou profess thyself, a knave or a fool?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: A fool, sir, at a woman's service, and a knave at a man's.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Your distinction?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I would cozen the man of his wife and do his service.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: So you were a knave at his service, indeed.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: And I would give his wife my bauble, sir, to do her service.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I will subscribe for thee, thou art both knave and fool.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: At your service.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: No, no, no.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Why, sir, if I cannot serve you, I can serve as great a prince as you are.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Who's that? a Frenchman?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Faith, sir, a' has an English name; but his fisnomy is more hotter in France than there.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: What prince is that?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: The black prince, sir; alias, the prince of darkness; alias, the devil.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I am a woodland fellow, sir, that always loved a great fire; and the master I speak of ever keeps a good fire. But, sure, he is the prince of the world; let his nobility remain in's court. I am for the house with the narrow gate, which I take to be too little for pomp to enter: some that humble themselves may; but the many will be too chill and tender, and they'll be for the flowery way that leads to the broad gate and the great fire.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Go thy ways, I begin to be aweary of thee; and I tell thee so before, because I would not fall out with thee. Go thy ways: let my horses be well looked to, without any tricks.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: If I put any tricks upon 'em, sir, they shall be jades' tricks; which are their own right by the law of nature.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: A shrewd knave and an unhappy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: So he is. My lord that's gone made himself much sport out of him: by his authority he remains here, which he thinks is a patent for his sauciness; and, indeed, he has no pace, but runs where he will.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I like him well; 'tis not amiss. And I was about to tell you, since I heard of the good lady's death and that my lord your son was upon his return home, I moved the king my master to speak in the behalf of my daughter; which, in the minority of them both, his majesty, out of a self-gracious remembrance, did first propose: his highness hath promised me to do it: and, to stop up the displeasure he hath conceived against your son, there is no fitter matter. How does your ladyship like it?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: With very much content, my lord; and I wish it happily effected.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: His highness comes post from Marseilles, of as able body as when he numbered thirty: he will be here to-morrow, or I am deceived by him that in such intelligence hath seldom failed.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: It rejoices me, that I hope I shall see him ere I die. I have letters that my son will be here to-night: I shall beseech your lordship to remain with me till they meet together.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Madam, I was thinking with what manners I might safely be admitted.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: You need but plead your honourable privilege.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Lady, of that I have made a bold charter; but I thank my God it holds yet.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: O madam, yonder's my lord your son with a patch of velvet on's face: whether there be a scar under't or no, the velvet knows; but 'tis a goodly patch of velvet: his left cheek is a cheek of two pile and a half, but his right cheek is worn bare.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: A scar nobly got, or a noble scar, is a good livery of honour; so belike is that.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: But it is your carbonadoed face.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Let us go see your son, I pray you: I long to talk with the young noble soldier.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Faith there's a dozen of 'em, with delicate fine hats and most courteous feathers, which bow the head and nod at every man.

scene.title: SCENE I. Marseilles. A street.

speech.stagedir: Enter HELENA, Widow, and DIANA, with two Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Marseilles. A street.
speech.text: But this exceeding posting day and night Must wear your spirits low; we cannot help it: But since you have made the days and nights as one, To wear your gentle limbs in my affairs, Be bold you do so grow in my requital As nothing can unroot you. In happy time; This man may help me to his majesty's ear, If he would spend his power. God save you, sir.

speech.stagedir: Enter HELENA, Widow, and DIANA, with two Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Marseilles. A street.
speech.text: And you.

speech.stagedir: Enter HELENA, Widow, and DIANA, with two Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Marseilles. A street.
speech.text: Sir, I have seen you in the court of France.

speech.stagedir: Enter HELENA, Widow, and DIANA, with two Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Marseilles. A street.
speech.text: I have been sometimes there.

speech.stagedir: Enter HELENA, Widow, and DIANA, with two Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Marseilles. A street.
speech.text: I do presume, sir, that you are not fallen From the report that goes upon your goodness; An therefore, goaded with most sharp occasions, Which lay nice manners by, I put you to The use of your own virtues, for the which I shall continue thankful.

speech.stagedir: Enter HELENA, Widow, and DIANA, with two Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Marseilles. A street.
speech.text: What's your will?

speech.stagedir: Enter HELENA, Widow, and DIANA, with two Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Marseilles. A street.
speech.text: That it will please you To give this poor petition to the king, And aid me with that store of power you have To come into his presence.

speech.stagedir: Enter HELENA, Widow, and DIANA, with two Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Marseilles. A street.
speech.text: The king's not here.

speech.stagedir: Enter HELENA, Widow, and DIANA, with two Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Marseilles. A street.
speech.text: Not here, sir!

speech.stagedir: Enter HELENA, Widow, and DIANA, with two Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Marseilles. A street.
speech.text: Not, indeed: He hence removed last night and with more haste Than is his use.

speech.stagedir: Enter HELENA, Widow, and DIANA, with two Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Marseilles. A street.
speech.text: Lord, how we lose our pains!

speech.stagedir: Enter HELENA, Widow, and DIANA, with two Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Marseilles. A street.
speech.text: All's well that ends well yet, Though time seem so adverse and means unfit. I do beseech you, whither is he gone?

speech.stagedir: Enter HELENA, Widow, and DIANA, with two Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Marseilles. A street.
speech.text: Marry, as I take it, to Rousillon; Whither I am going.

speech.stagedir: Enter HELENA, Widow, and DIANA, with two Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Marseilles. A street.
speech.text: I do beseech you, sir, Since you are like to see the king before me, Commend the paper to his gracious hand, Which I presume shall render you no blame But rather make you thank your pains for it. I will come after you with what good speed Our means will make us means.

speech.stagedir: Enter HELENA, Widow, and DIANA, with two Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Marseilles. A street.
speech.text: This I'll do for you.

speech.stagedir: Enter HELENA, Widow, and DIANA, with two Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Marseilles. A street.
speech.text: And you shall find yourself to be well thank'd, Whate'er falls more. We must to horse again. Go, go, provide.

scene.title: SCENE II. Rousillon. Before the COUNT's palace.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. Before the COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Good Monsieur Lavache, give my Lord Lafeu this letter: I have ere now, sir, been better known to you, when I have held familiarity with fresher clothes; but I am now, sir, muddied in fortune's mood, and smell somewhat strong of her strong displeasure.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. Before the COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Truly, fortune's displeasure is but sluttish, if it smell so strongly as thou speakest of: I will henceforth eat no fish of fortune's buttering. Prithee, allow the wind.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. Before the COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Nay, you need not to stop your nose, sir; I spake but by a metaphor.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. Before the COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Indeed, sir, if your metaphor stink, I will stop my nose; or against any man's metaphor. Prithee, get thee further.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. Before the COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Pray you, sir, deliver me this paper.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. Before the COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Foh! prithee, stand away: a paper from fortune's close-stool to give to a nobleman! Look, here he comes himself. Here is a purr of fortune's, sir, or of fortune's cat,--but not a musk-cat,--that has fallen into the unclean fishpond of her displeasure, and, as he says, is muddied withal: pray you, sir, use the carp as you may; for he looks like a poor, decayed, ingenious, foolish, rascally knave. I do pity his distress in my similes of comfort and leave him to your lordship.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. Before the COUNT's palace.
speech.text: My lord, I am a man whom fortune hath cruelly scratched.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. Before the COUNT's palace.
speech.text: And what would you have me to do? 'Tis too late to pare her nails now. Wherein have you played the knave with fortune, that she should scratch you, who of herself is a good lady and would not have knaves thrive long under her? There's a quart d'ecu for you: let the justices make you and fortune friends: I am for other business.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. Before the COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I beseech your honour to hear me one single word.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. Before the COUNT's palace.
speech.text: You beg a single penny more: come, you shall ha't; save your word.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. Before the COUNT's palace.
speech.text: My name, my good lord, is Parolles.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. Before the COUNT's palace.
speech.text: You beg more than 'word,' then. Cox my passion! give me your hand. How does your drum?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. Before the COUNT's palace.
speech.text: O my good lord, you were the first that found me!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. Before the COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Was I, in sooth? and I was the first that lost thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. Before the COUNT's palace.
speech.text: It lies in you, my lord, to bring me in some grace, for you did bring me out.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. Before the COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Out upon thee, knave! dost thou put upon me at once both the office of God and the devil? One brings thee in grace and the other brings thee out. The king's coming; I know by his trumpets. Sirrah, inquire further after me; I had talk of you last night: though you are a fool and a knave, you shall eat; go to, follow.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Rousillon. Before the COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I praise God for you.

scene.title: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.

speech.stagedir: Flourish. Enter KING, COUNTESS, LAFEU, the two French Lords, with Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: We lost a jewel of her; and our esteem Was made much poorer by it: but your son, As mad in folly, lack'd the sense to know Her estimation home.

speech.stagedir: Flourish. Enter KING, COUNTESS, LAFEU, the two French Lords, with Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.

speech.stagedir: Flourish. Enter KING, COUNTESS, LAFEU, the two French Lords, with Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: My honour'd lady, I have forgiven and forgotten all; Though my revenges were high bent upon him, And watch'd the time to shoot.

speech.stagedir: Flourish. Enter KING, COUNTESS, LAFEU, the two French Lords, with Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: This I must say, But first I beg my pardon, the young lord Did to his majesty, his mother and his lady Offence of mighty note; but to himself The greatest wrong of all. He lost a wife Whose beauty did astonish the survey Of richest eyes, whose words all ears took captive, Whose dear perfection hearts that scorn'd to serve Humbly call'd mistress.

speech.stagedir: Flourish. Enter KING, COUNTESS, LAFEU, the two French Lords, with Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Praising what is lost Makes the remembrance dear. Well, call him hither; We are reconciled, and the first view shall kill All repetition: let him not ask our pardon; The nature of his great offence is dead, And deeper than oblivion we do bury The incensing relics of it: let him approach, A stranger, no offender; and inform him So 'tis our will he should.

speech.stagedir: Flourish. Enter KING, COUNTESS, LAFEU, the two French Lords, with Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I shall, my liege.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: What says he to your daughter? have you spoke?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: All that he is hath reference to your highness.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Then shall we have a match. I have letters sent me That set him high in fame.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: He looks well on't.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I am not a day of season, For thou mayst see a sunshine and a hail In me at once: but to the brightest beams Distracted clouds give way; so stand thou forth; The time is fair again.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: My high-repented blames, Dear sovereign, pardon to me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: All is whole; Not one word more of the consumed time. Let's take the instant by the forward top; For we are old, and on our quick'st decrees The inaudible and noiseless foot of Time Steals ere we can effect them. You remember The daughter of this lord?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Admiringly, my liege, at first I stuck my choice upon her, ere my heart Durst make too bold a herald of my tongue Where the impression of mine eye infixing, Contempt his scornful perspective did lend me, Which warp'd the line of every other favour; Scorn'd a fair colour, or express'd it stolen; Extended or contracted all proportions To a most hideous object: thence it came That she whom all men praised and whom myself, Since I have lost, have loved, was in mine eye The dust that did offend it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Well excused: That thou didst love her, strikes some scores away From the great compt: but love that comes too late, Like a remorseful pardon slowly carried, To the great sender turns a sour offence, Crying, 'That's good that's gone.' Our rash faults Make trivial price of serious things we have, Not knowing them until we know their grave: Oft our displeasures, to ourselves unjust, Destroy our friends and after weep their dust Our own love waking cries to see what's done, While shame full late sleeps out the afternoon. Be this sweet Helen's knell, and now forget her. Send forth your amorous token for fair Maudlin: The main consents are had; and here we'll stay To see our widower's second marriage-day.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Which better than the first, O dear heaven, bless! Or, ere they meet, in me, O nature, cesse!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Come on, my son, in whom my house's name Must be digested, give a favour from you To sparkle in the spirits of my daughter, That she may quickly come. By my old beard, And every hair that's on't, Helen, that's dead, Was a sweet creature: such a ring as this, The last that e'er I took her at court, I saw upon her finger.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Hers it was not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Now, pray you, let me see it; for mine eye, While I was speaking, oft was fasten'd to't. This ring was mine; and, when I gave it Helen, I bade her, if her fortunes ever stood Necessitied to help, that by this token I would relieve her. Had you that craft, to reave her Of what should stead her most?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: My gracious sovereign, Howe'er it pleases you to take it so, The ring was never hers.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Son, on my life, I have seen her wear it; and she reckon'd it At her life's rate.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I am sure I saw her wear it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: You are deceived, my lord; she never saw it: In Florence was it from a casement thrown me, Wrapp'd in a paper, which contain'd the name Of her that threw it: noble she was, and thought I stood engaged: but when I had subscribed To mine own fortune and inform'd her fully I could not answer in that course of honour As she had made the overture, she ceased In heavy satisfaction and would never Receive the ring again.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Plutus himself, That knows the tinct and multiplying medicine, Hath not in nature's mystery more science Than I have in this ring: 'twas mine, 'twas Helen's, Whoever gave it you. Then, if you know That you are well acquainted with yourself, Confess 'twas hers, and by what rough enforcement You got it from her: she call'd the saints to surety That she would never put it from her finger, Unless she gave it to yourself in bed, Where you have never come, or sent it us Upon her great disaster.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: She never saw it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Thou speak'st it falsely, as I love mine honour; And makest conjectural fears to come into me Which I would fain shut out. If it should prove That thou art so inhuman,--'twill not prove so;-- And yet I know not: thou didst hate her deadly, And she is dead; which nothing, but to close Her eyes myself, could win me to believe, More than to see this ring. Take him away. My fore-past proofs, howe'er the matter fall, Shall tax my fears of little vanity, Having vainly fear'd too little. Away with him! We'll sift this matter further.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: If you shall prove This ring was ever hers, you shall as easy Prove that I husbanded her bed in Florence, Where yet she never was.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I am wrapp'd in dismal thinkings.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Gracious sovereign, Whether I have been to blame or no, I know not: Here's a petition from a Florentine, Who hath for four or five removes come short To tender it herself. I undertook it, Vanquish'd thereto by the fair grace and speech Of the poor suppliant, who by this I know Is here attending: her business looks in her With an importing visage; and she told me, In a sweet verbal brief, it did concern Your highness with herself.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Upon his many protestations to marry me when his wife was dead, I blush to say it, he won me. Now is the Count Rousillon a widower: his vows are forfeited to me, and my honour's paid to him. He stole from Florence, taking no leave, and I follow him to his country for justice: grant it me, O king! in you it best lies; otherwise a seducer flourishes, and a poor maid is undone. DIANA CAPILET.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I will buy me a son-in-law in a fair, and toll for this: I'll none of him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: The heavens have thought well on thee Lafeu, To bring forth this discovery. Seek these suitors: Go speedily and bring again the count. I am afeard the life of Helen, lady, Was foully snatch'd.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Now, justice on the doers!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I wonder, sir, sith wives are monsters to you, And that you fly them as you swear them lordship, Yet you desire to marry. What woman's that?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I am, my lord, a wretched Florentine, Derived from the ancient Capilet: My suit, as I do understand, you know, And therefore know how far I may be pitied.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I am her mother, sir, whose age and honour Both suffer under this complaint we bring, And both shall cease, without your remedy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Come hither, count; do you know these women?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: My lord, I neither can nor will deny But that I know them: do they charge me further?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Why do you look so strange upon your wife?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: She's none of mine, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Your reputation comes too short for my daughter; you are no husband for her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: My lord, this is a fond and desperate creature, Whom sometime I have laugh'd with: let your highness Lay a more noble thought upon mine honour Than for to think that I would sink it here.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Sir, for my thoughts, you have them ill to friend Till your deeds gain them: fairer prove your honour Than in my thought it lies.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Good my lord, Ask him upon his oath, if he does think He had not my virginity.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: What say'st thou to her?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: She's impudent, my lord, And was a common gamester to the camp.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: He does me wrong, my lord; if I were so, He might have bought me at a common price: Do not believe him. O, behold this ring, Whose high respect and rich validity Did lack a parallel; yet for all that He gave it to a commoner o' the camp, If I be one.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: He blushes, and 'tis it: Of six preceding ancestors, that gem, Conferr'd by testament to the sequent issue, Hath it been owed and worn. This is his wife; That ring's a thousand proofs.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Methought you said You saw one here in court could witness it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I did, my lord, but loath am to produce So bad an instrument: his name's Parolles.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I saw the man to-day, if man he be.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Find him, and bring him hither.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: What of him? He's quoted for a most perfidious slave, With all the spots o' the world tax'd and debosh'd; Whose nature sickens but to speak a truth. Am I or that or this for what he'll utter, That will speak any thing?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: She hath that ring of yours.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I think she has: certain it is I liked her, And boarded her i' the wanton way of youth: She knew her distance and did angle for me, Madding my eagerness with her restraint, As all impediments in fancy's course Are motives of more fancy; and, in fine, Her infinite cunning, with her modern grace, Subdued me to her rate: she got the ring; And I had that which any inferior might At market-price have bought.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I have it not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: What ring was yours, I pray you?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Sir, much like The same upon your finger.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Know you this ring? this ring was his of late.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: And this was it I gave him, being abed.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: The story then goes false, you threw it him Out of a casement.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I have spoke the truth.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: My lord, I do confess the ring was hers.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: You boggle shrewdly, every feather stars you. Is this the man you speak of?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Ay, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Tell me, sirrah, but tell me true, I charge you, Not fearing the displeasure of your master, Which on your just proceeding I'll keep off, By him and by this woman here what know you?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: So please your majesty, my master hath been an honourable gentleman: tricks he hath had in him, which gentlemen have.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Come, come, to the purpose: did he love this woman?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Faith, sir, he did love her; but how?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: How, I pray you?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: He did love her, sir, as a gentleman loves a woman.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: How is that?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: He loved her, sir, and loved her not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: As thou art a knave, and no knave. What an equivocal companion is this!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I am a poor man, and at your majesty's command.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: He's a good drum, my lord, but a naughty orator.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Do you know he promised me marriage?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Faith, I know more than I'll speak.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: But wilt thou not speak all thou knowest?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Yes, so please your majesty. I did go between them, as I said; but more than that, he loved her: for indeed he was mad for her, and talked of Satan and of Limbo and of Furies and I know not what: yet I was in that credit with them at that time that I knew of their going to bed, and of other motions, as promising her marriage, and things which would derive me ill will to speak of; therefore I will not speak what I know.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Thou hast spoken all already, unless thou canst say they are married: but thou art too fine in thy evidence; therefore stand aside. This ring, you say, was yours?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Ay, my good lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Where did you buy it? or who gave it you?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: It was not given me, nor I did not buy it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Who lent it you?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: It was not lent me neither.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Where did you find it, then?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I found it not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: If it were yours by none of all these ways, How could you give it him?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I never gave it him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: This woman's an easy glove, my lord; she goes off and on at pleasure.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: This ring was mine; I gave it his first wife.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: It might be yours or hers, for aught I know.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Take her away; I do not like her now; To prison with her: and away with him. Unless thou tell'st me where thou hadst this ring, Thou diest within this hour.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I'll never tell you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Take her away.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I'll put in bail, my liege.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: I think thee now some common customer.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: By Jove, if ever I knew man, 'twas you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Wherefore hast thou accused him all this while?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: She does abuse our ears: to prison with her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Good mother, fetch my bail. Stay, royal sir: The jeweller that owes the ring is sent for, And he shall surety me. But for this lord, Who hath abused me, as he knows himself, Though yet he never harm'd me, here I quit him: He knows himself my bed he hath defiled; And at that time he got his wife with child: Dead though she be, she feels her young one kick: So there's my riddle: one that's dead is quick: And now behold the meaning.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Is there no exorcist Beguiles the truer office of mine eyes? Is't real that I see?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Both, both. O, pardon!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: O my good lord, when I was like this maid, I found you wondrous kind. There is your ring; And, look you, here's your letter; this it says: 'When from my finger you can get this ring And are by me with child,' &c. This is done: Will you be mine, now you are doubly won?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: If she, my liege, can make me know this clearly, I'll love her dearly, ever, ever dearly.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: If it appear not plain and prove untrue, Deadly divorce step between me and you! O my dear mother, do I see you living?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Mine eyes smell onions; I shall weep anon: Good Tom Drum, lend me a handkercher: so, I thank thee: wait on me home, I'll make sport with thee: Let thy courtesies alone, they are scurvy ones.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.
speech.text: Let us from point to point this story know, To make the even truth in pleasure flow. If thou be'st yet a fresh uncropped flower, Choose thou thy husband, and I'll pay thy dower; For I can guess that by thy honest aid Thou keep'st a wife herself, thyself a maid. Of that and all the progress, more or less, Resolvedly more leisure shall express: All yet seems well; and if it end so meet, The bitter past, more welcome is the sweet.
